text:
After reading the reviews I did the following - I bought 4 lb pork butt - a less expensive cut of meat.  I put the meat and broth in the slow cooker for 10 hours, shredded it right away (it shredded very easily) added 1 1/2 bottles of barbecue sauce and refrigerated it overnight.  The next day I put it back in the slow cooker for a couple of hours to reheat.  It was delicious, easy and inexpensive.

text:
This is how I cook my bbq pork.  Recommendation for those who have used pork tenderloin, boneless pork chops, etc., - you're using an expensive cut of meat when the cheap cuts work as well.  Honestly, the pork will be very tender and the flavor rich.  It only takes a small amount of work to remove the bones & fat.  The meat itself remains reasonably lean.  You will save much money by trying the pork butt, pork roast, etc.

text:
The way i made this turned out excellent!  I used approximately 5.5 lbs of pork ribs with the bone since i coulldn't find boneless.  

I made my own sauce from a Taste Of Home recipe i have for pork ribs.  Plain bottled sauce seemed like it wouldn't taste good.  

The recipe i used for the sauce is:

1/2 cup cider vinegar
1/2 cup packed brown sugar
1/2 cup ketchup
1/4 cup chili sauce
1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce
2 tbsp chopped onions
1 tbsp lemon juice
1/2 tsp ground mustard
1 clove garlic, minced
dash cayenne pepper

Combine all sauce ingredients in a saucepan. Simmer, uncovered, for 1 hour or until slightly thickened, stirring occasionally.

text:
Here's a really good modification of this recipe.  Throw your pork in a slow cooker with no liquid (or maybe a little water if it's a really lean cut) and cook until it's done.  Then shred it and pour in a bottle of good vinegary barbeque sauce and most of a can of cola, and leave the top off the slow cooker (should still be at high) for about an hour to thicken the sauce.  This takes out the oven step, and the soda in it is surprisingly delicious.  Of course it smells so good I can hardly wait that last hour, so I sometimes speed things up in a big skillet.  Enjoy!

text:
Really, really good.  Again, I always follow the recipe exactly the first time I make it and this time I was glad I had.  I was very tempted, like others, to just throw the sauced meat back into the crock pot--I mean, why mess up another pan, right?  Well I think it made a big, positive difference to the final product.  The time in the oven kindof browns the tips and makes it seem more like meat done on the grill.  I'd never used Sweet Baby Ray's before and it was good with the pork.  It was a little sweet, obviously--I may use Bullseye next time for a more savory change of pace.  I will definately be making this again.

text:
Wow this BBQ was a huge hit.  Following the advice of my butcher I used Boston Butt instead of boneless ribs.  I cooked the meat for 8 hours the night before the party, drained and shredded it and stored it back in the crockpot overnight in the fridge.  About 4 hours before the event I added the Sweet Baby Ray's (don't settle for kc masterpiece - yuck) and some of the left over stock drained from the crock the night before.  So amazing, I will be making this again!

text:
I followed the advice of another review and cooked the pork for 10 hours, pulled it and drained the broth, and then let the pork marinate in the BBQ sauce over night and reheated it the next day.  I would suggest the beginning part (cook the pork in the broth for about 10 hours and then pull the pork/drain the broth) but then I would mix the BBQ sauce right in and just warm it up....then eat it.  By marinating it over night and reheating it the pork became mush and there was hardly any texture.  I am a big texture person, so it was hard to eat that way.  I would rather have bigger chunks of pork than mush.  Otherwise, this was amazing, especially with the original Jack Daniel's BBQ sauce.  I would highly suggest making this and we will be making it again!

text:
This recipe is impossible to screw up...also, everyone we've tried this (about ten times)on loves it.  After experimenting a bit, we've settled on the following: pepper then brown pork (shoulder or butt cut) chop med - large onion, put in bottom of slow cooker with browned meet on top, then pour on 1/2-3/4 bottle of smoke/bbq sauce, cook for 8-10 hours, remove bone(s) and large pieces of fat, shred meat, put back in the cooker, mix with the leftover bbq sauce then switch to high for 1/2-1 hr.  serve on rolls with beer

text:
I used this recipe and the ideas of Jan's (submitted Feb.2001). It was absolutely delicious! Used a boneless shoulder cut of pork since it tends to be leaner. Peppered and seasoned pork using Lawry's seasoning, browned the meat. Chopped med onion added to bottom of slow cooker. Added one can of beef broth and 1/2cup of your favorite BBQ Sauce (a good sauce also makes the difference in taste, we prefer a sweet/spicy sauce)-cooked in slow cooker on low for 3-4 hours, until meat was tender and ready to fall apart. Drained broth, shredded the meat, mix rest of BBQ sauce, cooked to desired temp. approx 1/2-1 hour in cooker. This is definately a repeat recipe in our home for many years to come!

text:
I made it the first time just as this recipe calls for and it was ok. I was expecting more than the bbq sauce having to give it the flavor, and plus my husband was not even interested in taking a 2nd sandwich. the second time i made it i used a 3 lb boston butt (pork shoulder) and rubbed it with 1tsp of each- seasoning salt, ground black pepper, onion powder, garlic powder and sage. By the way sage goes great with pork! Then i put it in the crock pot with only 1 cup water. Didnt use beef broth because of the extra salt, water works just as perfect. let it cook on low 6-8 hrs until its fall apart perfect with a touch of the fork. take it out and let it sit for 10 minutes and discard the cooking liquids. Shred it up with 2 forks or your fingers. put it back in the crock pot, coat it with BBQ sauce (sweet baby rays :-)) and let it sit for 1 more hr on low. My husband will now eat half the pot!

text:
Having made a variation of this many times, I can say that the step of cooking the meat in beef broth is unnecessary and though I did do that this time, I noticed no difference than had I not. I have always cooked the meat first with nothing added, shredded it, then returned it to the slow cooker with the BBQ sauce to cook another hour or so. I can also say that this is as good as the barbecue sauce used. In this case, I agree with hubs' comment that it was the "Jim Neely's Interstate Barbecue Sauce" we brought back from Memphis that made this so tasty.

text:
Wow, this came out awesome.  I used 2lbs of Pork Roast Butt.  I did everything else nearly the same.  I increased the time in the crock pot by 1/2 hr on low, in addition to the 4hrs on high.  I also didn't have a cast iron skillet  or pan so I put the pulled pork in a prepared with Pam casserole dish.  My husband said it was the best pulled pork he ever had! He orders this all the time at restaurants and now said he doesn't like the restaurant ones nearly as much as this homemade version.  He had it again for breakfast the next day!  It was gone before you know it!   He said he wants me to make this for him every week.  It was so easy to make, the only thing that took any time was pulling the pork apart with forks.  This was no effort and no time.  I love this recipe and so does my husband.  Thank you for posting it!    UPDATE:  I made this again several times, but this last time I used a beef chuck roast, 2lbs and WOW it was so good!  We had friends over and they just died over how freakin good this is and how easy!  I did nothing at all different!  I just made sure that when I pulled apart the beef I got rid of as much of the fat as possible and it was super wonderful.  Also, I used 3 different BBQ sauces,  about 16ounces for 2 lbs each time I did this.  The extra BBQ sauce is real important because when it goes in the oven for the last 30minutes (which you gotta do to get those brown tips, mmm) anyway, in the oven step, the heat from the oven sucks out some of the juices.

text:
I love this two step method of cooking - the slow cooker makes it tender and the black skillet oven time enhances the texture and provides those delicious little "burnt ends" that we all love. A good tip: after removing the meat from the slow cooker and pulling it and blending it with the sauce, I add about 1/4 c of the juices from the cooker to the meat before turning it into the skillet (which I already have hot by warming in the oven during the pre-heat.)  This aids the charring and caramelizing while helping to keep the bulk of the meat juicy tender.   Taste is subject to your seasoning and sauce; for mine I use half Bull's Eye Original and half Moonlite BBQ (local specialty from Owensboro, KY) plus 3T molasses or brown sugar, and 1T Frank's hot sauce for a spicy-sweet flavor. I also add one whole sweet onion (sliced very thin) to the slow cooker pot before the meat goes in, plus 1/2 tsp liquid smoke to the beef broth/ beer / cola.  No matter which cut of meat I've used, or which form of liquid, as long as I've stayed true to the method, I've ALWAYS produced a crowd pleaser with this recipe. Thank you KMB233 for sharing!

text:
Super Good!!!! I used a pork butt instead of the ribs -- cheaper and just as good, as others have mentioned.  I omitted the beef broth, as my butt had enough fat on it already *blushing*.  Followed the rest of the recipe exactly.  I used Sweet Baby Ray’s bbq sauce (my fave) and did the oven thingy.  I think baking it in the oven for the last 30 minutes is a crucial step; it just gives it a wonderful texture so it’s not so soupy after slow cooking all day.  I served over toasted hamburger buns, with a green salad on the side.  Even my 17 year-old-daughter (who hates everything and everybody) loooved it :)  I would definitely make this again.

text:
This continues to be a family favorite - to the point where I gave both of my adult sons a cast iron skillet, a bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's Honey BBQ sauce, and the recipe typed on a card as an extra Christmas gift.  It's delicious,and easy.  Using a pork butt is the trick -- cheaper and meatier.  One son prefers Jack Daniels BBQ sauce. I would suggest having the bottle at the table as well.  I cook it for 10 hours on low and the meat shreds perfectly - comes out a bit chunky, which is what I prefer.  The last 30 minutes in the oven is the trick -- the sauce sticks better to the pork.  My mouth is watering as I'm typing this!

text:
This was absolutely delicious! I used a 4 lb. pork butt which was less expensive and just as good. Seasoned the meat generously with salt, pepper and garlic powder. I then sliced one onion and put it under the meat with the beef broth. After 5 hours on high the meat shredded beautifully. I mixed 1 1/2 bottles of Sweet Baby Ray's Honey BBQ sauce into the pulled pork before putting it in the oven as directed for 20 minutes. Do not skip this step! The sauce caramelizes and becomes the perfect consistency. I served the pulled pork on potato roll buns with a side of baked beans. This was better than any pulled pork I've ever had before. I had a house full of happy guys.

text:
The recipe I used for the sauce is: 1/2 cup cider vinegar --- 1/2 cup brown sugar --- 1/2 cup ketchup --- 1 tsp chili powder --- 1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce --- 2 tbsp chopped onions --- 1 tbsp lemon juice --- 1/2 tsp ground mustard (substitute with premade mustard) --- 1 clove garlic --- dash cayenne pepper. Threw sauce and pork ribs in slow cooker for 6 hours then I shredded the meat. Last of all, I made the drippings thicker by adding cornstarch after cooking the pork.

text:
This recipe was amazing!  My guests all went back for seconds, but I did make a few changes.  I used 4 lbs. of pork shoulder, which I rubbed with a mix of the following:  3 tablespoons brown sugar, 2 tablespoons Emeril's Essence seasoning, 1 tablespoon salt,1 tablespoon ground cumin,1 tablespoon paprika,1 tablespoon freshly ground black pepper,1 tablespoon cayenne.  I let it sit overnight, then cooked it on low for 9 hours with 1/2 can of beef broth.  Then I strained the liquid, shredded the pork, removed the bones and fat, mixed in a bottle of bbq sauce, and then put it back in the slow cooker until warm.  Served on potato rolls with cole slaw and corn and black bean salad.

text:
I don't often use a crockpot, but this is one recipe that I will keep.  It is perfect for days when you know that you will be late getting home and yet you still want to feed your famaily a good hearty meal.  Just add a tossed salad on the side and maybe some corn and you're good to go. I make my own barbeque sauce in gallon quantities that I am partial to. Before I started making my own sauce, I found that Sweet Baby Ray's is one of the best on the market and am sure that it would definately do this recipe justice.  Please don't ruin this recipe by using KC Masterpiece, you might as well throw in ketchup, mustard and brown sugar. Ick

I don't see how this could be much easier.  I put the ribs in the crockpot on low and cooked them overnight.  I used the beef broth, some chopped onion and 1 teaspoon of liquid smoke.  This morning I drained the liquid, shredded the meat and then added the BBQ sauce.  Put back in the clean crock pot and heated for 2 more hours.  Delicious!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I served this for my daughters 1st birthday party where there were over 20 people. It went over really well. I did change things a little bit. I used a 7lb pork roast ($1.98/lb) and put it in the slow cooker for about 10 hours or so. After that, I shredded it and added the bbq sauce (Sweet Baby Rays in my case) and put it in the fridge over night. The next day I put it all in a 13 x 9 and added more bbq and baked it at 400 for about 40 minutes. Then I served it in the crock to keep it warm. Turned out great, takes a bit of planning time-wise but is easy and very economical.

Display Name:
caseyboggs7

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/672916.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband has said my pulled pork could easily win contests. I buy 3 lbs pork shoulder and sprinkle jerk seasoning and french thyme very heavily on the shoulder as a rub and chop a medium white onion, throw that into the pot/partially on top of shoulder and pour 1.5 cups cola over the entire thing. set it on low to cook 8.5 hours, then cut the cord and hand pull the pork to a thick--medium consistency and return it to the crock pot, pour 2 cups sweet baby ray's bbq over everything and set it on high to cook 30-40 mins. serve on hamburger buns with twice baked potatoes and a bud lite and you've got yourself an amazing dinner, plus about 4 lunches and 2 more dinners worth of appetizers. that is if its just you and your hubby ;)

text:
Wow, this was way better than I was expecting, and I was expecting it to be delicious. I couldn't stop eating little pieces of meat after dinner, it made me quite carnivorous. Here's what we did:  Boston Pork Butt (paid $4.60) Thawed in Fridge overnight (ours was frozen) Put in slow cooker on low Covered with 1 can of beef broth and 1 cup of water that I dissolved 2 beef bouillon cubes in with a spoonful of jarred minced garlic. I put it in right before work and DH shred it with a fork at 4:30 (9 hours). The 20-30 minutes in the oven is like the icing on the cake, makes it crispy around the edges. Don't skip that part. Thanks the the person who submitted this original recipe, it's awesome!!!

text:
This is great for a party!  It's easy to double (if you have a large crock pot), and easy to make ahead of time.  I cooked the pork the day before (using a few cuts of pork roast, in addition to boneless ribs), shredded it the morning of the party, and reheated it in the crock pot with the barbeque sauce and some of the beef broth for a few hours before the party.  Other than the shredding, it's a quick and easy meal!

Edit: Have made this many times over, and still the best and easiest pulled pork bbq ever!  Use the cheap cuts of pork, as it will just fall apart and be super easy to shred.  Try different sauces with this.  Our favorite now is to mix two sauces: Jack Daniels hickory and Texas Mopping Sauce.  Topped with coleslaw I'd give this ten stars if I could! Original review: This is the absolute BEST barbecue ever!  It was so easy to fix, too!  All three of my boys ate this up, even the pickiest of the bunch!  I used KC Masterpiece original sauce to finish it up, and that added just enough sweetness to make this delicious.  This would be great with some coleslaw added to the sandwich, or on the side, and some good fries.  Happy eating with this recipe!  Thanks KK!

DELICIOUS!  I followed reviewer Ginger's advice and went with a 4lb Pork Butt instead of ribs. I didn't start the meat the night before as Ginger had suggested, but it still turned out awesome, tender and delicious!

country:

text:
This was my first time trying BBQ Pork and OH MY OH MY was it delicious. I took a look at the other reviews before I settled on my switch-up recipe. I got the thick slabs of boneless ribs, I would have gotten shoulder/butt, however it was like 8lbs. (too large for my little family). I put it all in the crock-pot, popped open a bottle of budlite, poured it in along with 1/3cup of Sweet-Baby Ray's and let it go on LOW for about 10 hours without messing with it. It stopped cooking in the middle of the night and I let it sit till the morning - then I shredded it, cut a whole white onion put it on the bottom of the crock-pot put the pork right on top and put another good bit of Sweet-Baby Ray's on top and let it cook on LOW another 3-4 hours. You're talking good -- The last suggestion I would make would be adding some Texas Pete Hot sauce on top just to give it a zip and I like my sandwhich prepared with coleslaw and the pork on a toasted bun. This recipe is delicious and now one of my fave's!

text:
I love pulled pork and never knew I could make it at home, without a big smoke pit in the backyard! I used a 3 lb boneless pork shoulder. It was in the crock pot for 10 hrs on low, since I was gone that long - I think 8 or 9 hrs would have been great. It was so easy to shred with a fork, and easy to remove the fat at the same time. Finished in the oven with the Sweet Baby Rays. I lightly buttered some large bakery hamburger buns and set them under the broiler just until they were toasty. Piled on the meat, added a slice of oinion and a few dill pickle slices. Served with cole slaw and french fries. My husband said it was the best pork sandwich he'd ever had. Wasn't sure how my friend's 11 year daughter would like it, but she ate the entire sandwich in no time and reported it great. Thanks so much for posting this recipe. I will definitely be making this again and again!

I will do what someone said- 4 lb pork butt - a less expensive cut of meat. the meat and broth in the slow cooker for 10 hours, shredded it right away (it shredded very easily) added 1 1/2 bottles of barbecue sauce and refrigerated it overnight. The next day I put it back in the slow cooker for a couple of hours to reheat. It was delicious, easy and inexpensive.  pork butt or pork roast

text:
Excellent! Started with a 4 1/4 lb pork loin roast (was on sale) & cut in half to fit the slow cooker; put a Montreal Seasoning rub into it & cooked on high for 3 1/2 hrs. before shredding it; drained the broth & added 1 1/2 bottles of Famous Dave's BBQ Sauce right back into the slow cooker before adding the shredded pork back in. Let it simmer on high another hour then kept on warm thru an extended dinner. Served it up on bakery sub rolls. Perfection!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so delicious! Made a couple easy changes: I used pork tenderloin and it was fantastic. I seasoned it with montreal steak seasoning and seared it for a couple minutes on each side. Put in the crock pot with the can of beef broth and about half of an onion (sliced however you like). It was ready to shred after 4 hours on high. I dumped the onions out with the used broth. Then I dumped a bottle of Sweet Baby Rays on it, put it back in the crock pot on low for an hour and bam, ready to go. We like to add a little Famous Dave's "Devil's Spit" sauce on each individual sandwich. My husband thinks this is even better the next day after it's been in the fridge. Make it with some baked beans and potato salad and it's a great BBQ meal!

text:
Great recipe for pulled pork!  I have never tried this version before of using the beef broth.  But it sure seemed to make that pork tender!  I used a 2 lb. pork loin and cooked it on low for an hour and high the last 3 hours.  After shredding I poured out most of the broth and added just enough to moisten the meat.  Instead of putting it in the oven I just dumped some bbq sauce in the crock and let it heat thru.  I may try the oven next time because Im sure the higher heat will help the bbq sauce to really get thick and caramelize.  Thanks for the recipe!  I definitely will use this method again to make juicy, tender crockpot pork!

userID:
7778391
Display Name:
mary_o
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3654385.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this 3 times now (doubling the recipe one time) and can attest to how easy and yummy this recipe is.  On the advice of other reviewers, I used bone-in pork shoulder because of the cost.  I am a fanatic about removing the fat, and after this last time, I think I may use a leaner cut of pork if I can find it on sale.  Only reason being it made a super quick and easy recipe more tedious and time consuming than necessary.  Of course, if you don't mind some fat in your pork or don't mind picking it all out, then the cost difference is worth it.  The flavor is great and the recipe couldn't be easier.  I put a 3-1/2 to 4 lb pork shoulder, along with the beef broth, into a 6 qt slow cooker.  I cooked it on low for 10 hours, turning it once.  I then removed the pork, and shredded and de-fatted it with 2 forks.  Like I said, the de-fatting part was time consuming, but the meat just fell apart...so easy.  I rinsed out the crockpot, returned the pork to it,added my bbq sauce and let sit in the fridge over-night.  A couple hours before serving, I put it back on the crockpot on "warm" and served on warmed Hawaiian Rolls.  YUM!!  Tried Stubbs and Sweet Baby Rays...much prefer the SBR and will use that from now on.

text:
This recipe is good everytime, but the cut of meat is important.  I look for country style pork ribs with the least amount of fat possible.  The more fat, the worse the house smells during cooking.  I made the mistake once of getting some fatty ribs and the house smelled like a rendering plant.  Since then my husband makes me use the slow cooker out in the garage for this recipe.

text:
I misread someone elses review and decided to add BOTH a can of cola and a can of beef broth. Fate? I think so. Taste was exquisite. I put the cola, broth, and pork BUTT in the slow cooker and set it at 6 hours on high. Meat fell off the bone VERY easily. After shredding the meat (and removing the bone), I added the bottle of BBQ sauce (sweet baby rays). Set it the low @ 12 hours setting...WITHOUT the lid (until the sauce thickens). After it thickened...BAM!!! Yummy goodness! Thank you for the suggestions and recipe!

text:
As others have suggested, it is not necessary to use ribs.  I used a pork shoulder roast that I purchased on sale.  Instead of a whole can of beef broth, I used 1 cup and reserved the rest.  I cooked the roast on low in the slow cooker for about 8 hours, drained all the liquid, removed the bone and any fat, and shredded the meat.  I then added the reserved beef broth and a bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ Sauce and cooked another hour on low.  Yum!

text:
I used Country boneless ribs. I put them in the crockpot, with a can of beef broth, half of a large chopped white onion, garlic powder, and a little sea salt. I cooked on high for 3 1/2 hours. By this time they were falling apart. I scooped all the meat up, separated it (it falls apart), put it in a dish and drenched it with my own personal barbecue sauce (If you don't make your own barbecue sauce, I suggest you use Sweet Baby Ray's. ). Put in a 350 degree oven for 20 minutes. Serve on warm buns with a side of barbecue sauce. My family loved this recipe and I will be using it at least once a month.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am not big on pork but my husband had been begging me to make pulled pork sandwhiches.  Thank you for a great recipe!  I did a couple things different though based on other suggestions.  I bought a lean pork roast and chopped 1 med onion in the bottom of the crock pot.  I seasoned the meat with salt and pepper and then put in in the skillet just to brown the outside.  Then put in in the crock pot and poured can of broth on top and 1/2 cup BBQ sauce.  I cooked it on low in crock pot for 4 hours.  Drained and shredded meat...I also kept some of the onions with the meat for extra flavor.  Then I transferred it back in the crock pot and poured the remainder of the BBQ sauce in it and let it cook for 1 hour.  Hubby thought it was delicious served with potato salad and I even tried some and it was very very tasty.

text:
This was the first time I've ever cooked pork ribs. I wasn't expecting to like it much at all...not a big pork fan, but my husband loves pulled pork, so I gave it a try. It gets five stars for simplicity alone...it fell off the bone after cooking in the broth. I didn't cook it in the oven after shredding...that seemed like a totally unnecessary step. I just put it back in the crock pot, added the sauce and let it cook until we were ready to eat. Served it on buns with cole slaw, which it definitely needed to cut the sweet/fat of the pork and sauce.

text:
This deserves to be rated as a 5-Star recipe because it was delicious!!  The recipe was very easy to follow and the ingredients very easy to find.  The only thing I did different was marinate the meat in a rib rub I put together with ingredients in my cupboard (brown sugar, onion powder, garlic powder, ground mustard, paprika, cayenne pepper, black pepper, and salt).  I let it sit in the refrigerator for a few hours.  I then followed the recipe as listed.   I think it's important to choose a good quality sauce that tastes great! I used Sweet Baby Ray's Original both times I made this.  I may use the spicy one next time.  This is so good that I will no longer buy a pulled pork sandwich when I go out to eat...because I know I can make a better one right at home.  This is my new favorite recipe!

I was skeptical, but wanted to try it this way without complicating it like I usually do – the slow-cooker is supposed to make life easier! I didn't make a rub, I didn't marinate, I didn't make a BBQ sauce from scratch, and it was delicious. I used a 4.5 lb. butt roast, 10-hrs on low. MUST bake in oven for 30-min. to "crisp" it up a bit as recipe states. MUST serve with cole-slaw on soft rolls!

text:
I have made this twice now-the first time I skipped the oven step and the second time I didn't (totally makes a difference-don't skip it!). The baking step gave it a nice texture and really brought out the flavor of the pork. I used a pork shoulder and just made sure I removed all of the fat before shredding. After shredding it and covering it with only a half bottle of sauce I let it sit overnight and baked it the next day. Really yummy!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
A great recipe but I have one issue with some of the reviewers recommendations re: sauce.  I can find only a very few sauces that do not  have high fructose corn syrup as a main ingredient.  All that I read about this ingredient says AVOID.  Thus - I have found a couple of good ones that do not have that ingredient.  Georgia South BBQ sauce and Chocktaw Willies sauces.  Have tried the GA South and it's very good.  Will try CW's in a few days.  It sounds good as well.  And just maybe it's better for you.  Course - bbq can only be so good for you since it is sooooo good period......

We've used this recipe many times and have changed it up with different types of meat (chicken, beef),broth (veggie, chicken) and BBQ sauce (too many to list).  EVERY time it has turned out perfect.  If it isn't on the menu in our house, someone is craving it anyway.

Great original recipe and versatile as well!  Love it KK!

text:
Wow, this was so easy, and it turned out fantastic!  I never need to buy BBQ pork again!  I used 4 lb of pork butt, trimmed the fat and bones, and cooked it for 5 hours on high.  After shredding the meat, I took another reviewer's suggestion and put it back in the slow cooker with the KC Masterpiece BBQ sauce and 2 ladles of broth.  Then I let it cook for 1 hour on low, and it was scrumptious!  Thanks!  I will definitely make this again.

text:
Well, after seeing 5 stars, I had high hopes, unfortunately, this was WAY TOO MOIST, and I cooked it for at least 45 minutes in the oven uncovered.  I used a Boston Butt, and I should have known better than to put all that stock back into the pork, but I'm kinda a stickler for following the recipes instructions the first time, as it drives me nuts to see people rate something real high or real low and see where they changed half the recipe.  I liked the flavors though and took the leftovers and put in a toaster oven on a cooking sheet and cooked them for another 30 minutes and they turned out much much better, but as written, be careful, pour out half the stock, chop it up and then evaluate, you can always take that leftover stock and wet it afterwards if its a bit too dry once it comes out of the oven.  I think it needed a touch of garlic and a bit more complex flavors, but it was not bad, but definitely not worthy of 5 stars.

country:

text:
Whooaaaa...

So if you can't tell by my screen name, I'm a vegetarian. I was planning a huge co ed baby shower luau and was trying to figure out a way to feed 30 carnivorous friends without breaking the bank. 

I used a 12 lb pork shoulder butt, 1 bottle of beer, and one can of beef broth and cooked it on low for 10 hours. 

Instead of bottled barbeque sauce I made my own Hawaiian bbq sauce with pineapple juice, teriyaki sauce, ketchup, fresh garlic, minced shallots, and fresh ginger. 

My hubby shredded it for me, I stirred in the sauce and refridgerated it until 30 min before the guests arrived. Heated it for 30 min in the oven, and served with mini Hawaiian rolls.

It was a BIG hit! And so easy...

If a vegetarian can pull this off, so can you!

text:
5 stars for just how simple this is.  You can't got wrong with this recipe.  I usually omit the beef broth and just use meat and a bottle of sauce and it still comes out great.  Also, I don't finish it in the oven.  I just put it back into the crock pot for about 30-60 mins. and occasionally add a little more BBQ sauce.  Do use a good quality BBQ sauce since it's the only ingredient for flavor.  This makes excellent sandwiches.    A variation: I use 4 frozen boneless chicken breasts and about 1/2 a bottle of BBQ sauce to make great sandwiches as well and super quick.  I always have a bag of frozen chicken in the freezer.

text:
FANTASTIC! I used Pork Shoulder - 3.5 lbs sprinkled with salt, pepper and garlic powder. Browned all sides in a little oil in medium hot skillet , then added the pork to crock pot with sliced onions underneath the pork. Didn't have beef broth so I added 1/2 to 3/4 c water to the pan I browned the pork in and scraped up the browned bits on the bottom. Dumped this in the crock pot as well. Cooked on low 7 hours. Meat was so flavorful and just melted apart. The juices were phenomenal too. Used half the meat for soft tacos. Best I've had! Added warmed BBQ sauce to the other half and toasted buns for sandwiches. Thank you for such a versatile, easy, delicious recipe.

userID:
5080150
Display Name:
Scien
isPro:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/436362.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first attempt at pulled pork.  I followed some of the suggestions below because they made sense to me.  Bought a 4lb pork butt at what I think was a reasonable price (dunno, never bought the stuff before).  Cut once to let it fit in the slow cooker.  Used two cans of beer for the liquid, and slow cooked for 10 hours.  Checked on it a few times at that time and pressed down to keep the meat under the liquid.  After the time was up, pulled the meat out of the liquid, grabbing any obvious fat globs and discarding with liquid.  Pulled apart using two forks, and again removed obviously over fatty parts.  Added about 1.5 bottles of BBQ sauce to taste, probably could have used more.  Let sit in fridge a day (I hear that pulled pork is better day old).  After which got some buns, browned on stove top, served meat reheated with thick onions, dill pickles, and mustard.  For a bachelor like me, big success for little work.  Awesome.

userID:

Display Name:
jessie.f

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious! I used pork butt or pork shoulder and it is so incredibly cheap and it feeds an army.  I usually get a 7 pounder and cook it for about ten to twelve hours on low.  First I season the pork with garlic powder, onion powder, pepper and adobe.  I put it in the slow cooker and cover it with beef broth and let it cook for ten hours.  During this time i make my own bbq sauce (compliments of amethystshells review - which is amazing) -1/2 cup cider vinegar 1/2 cup packed brown sugar 1/2 cup ketchup 1/4 cup chili sauce 1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce 2 tbsp chopped onions 1 tbsp lemon juice 1/2 tsp ground mustard 1 clove garlic, minced dash cayenne pepper Combine all sauce ingredients in a saucepan. Simmer, uncovered, for 1 hour or until slightly thickened, stirring occasionally.    I pour that over the pulled pork when done and heat it in the oven for an hour. Don't forget to serve with coleslaw!

text:
DELICIOUS and SIMPLE!!!  I had this recipe in my box for some time and wanted to try it using a less expensive cut of meat.  Was at our local butcher's today and they had pork butt on sale for $1.99 a pound.  After reading the reviews many used a pork butt so I decided to give it a try.  Put the pork in the crockpot at midnight with the beef broth ONLY for 10 hours.  Shredded the meat while still warm.  I was surprised at the amount of fat there was with this boneless 4.5 pork butt.  The meat tasted so good without the bbq sauce !!!  After shredding I ladling a few cups of the beef broth onto the meat to keep from drying out.  I topped with Big Al's BBQ sauce recipe.  I will definitely make this again soon!

More than 5 stars!  Absolutely fabulous. Giving this only 4 stars as I didnt follow the recipe:  
I got a 3LB boneless pork shoulder or butt roast (whatever is available) from my local asian market butcher counter.  Dont waste your $$ on an expensive cut of meat - The crockpot will make the meat tender anyway.  I've found that for a cheaper cut of meat, the asian market butcher counter is the best place to go.  Most chain grocrey stores only sell 7+lb bone-in roasts which is too much for my family.  Anyway, I seasoned the meat with pepper and mrs dash and placed it in the crockpot with NO liquid.  The meat will create its own drippings.  Cook on low for 10hrs.  Remove meat from crockpot, drain (save drippings), and shred meat removing as much fat from it as possible.  Place shredded meat back in the crockpot changing the setting to warm.  Some may let the drippings cool, even putting it in the freezer to make skimming off the fat easier.  But since I've got a hungry troop to feed, I dont wait and just spoon the fat off the top and pour the remaining back over the meat.  
I either make my own BBQ sauce (Recipe from Brisket with BBQ Sauce) or heat up some original Sweet Baby Ray's sauce in a saucepan.  I let everyone add however much sauce they want on their individual portions.  
Very tasty and very easy recipe!

text:
YUM!  Everyone enjoyed this dish.  The easiest thing i have ever made!  I bought a 5 pounds pork loin roast at Costco and threw it in my Crock Pot on low for 7 hrs.  Added 2 cans of beef broth because i used so much meat.  I also sliced up 1/2 a yellow onion and 2 cloves of garlic and addded it to the beef broth.  Left in in the crock pot for 7 hrs on low and the meat just fell apart!!  added the BBQ sauce (made my own) and it was to die for!  Served on buttered and toasted hamburger buns... DELISH!  would recommend this recipe to anyone!! By the way... the 5 lb made enough for 12 sandwiches... I only had 4 people eating... but everyone ate 2!!  The leftovers were even better the next day!

text:
WOW!!!  This recipe is FANTASTIC!  My husband prepared it with a little direction from me.  You have to understand that he does *not* cook. ;)  It was just the best BBQ that we have ever tasted....and that includes the BBQ we ate in Memphis that, until making this recipe, was our favorite.  We made the recipe using 5 lbs. of boneless pork loin which was on sale for $1.89 per pound at our market.  We just put that in the crock pot with two cans of beef stock and let it cook for about 6 hours on high.  Then, we removed all visible fat and shredded the meat.  (The meat was SUPER easy to shred.)  We then put it in the oven as stated in the recipe.  We used Sweet Baby Ray's original sauce as recommended by many other reviewers.  It came out absolutely PERFECT!  We will be making this again and again and definately will use it when whole, boneless pork loins are on sale! Tons of awesome food for very little money! Thanks for a GREAT recipe!

text:
Delicious! I put a 5 lb. pork shoulder in the crock pot with about a cup of chicken broth and a diced onion and let it cook on low overnight (About 10 hours).  In the morning I trimmed off all the fat, shredded it and added Sweet Baby Ray's regular BBQ sauce. The secret is definitely cooking it in the oven for the extra 30 minutes! I added a little of the broth from the crock pot, plus the diced onion and the flavors melded together sooo well!  My boyfriend said this was better than pulled pork sandwiches he's eaten at restaurants!  Will definitely make again!

text:
Even though there are tons of reviews on this one, I had to throw my 2 cents in! This recipe came to my rescue tonight. Several weeks ago, I'd bought a 2-lb "value pack of assorted pork cuts" from my grocery store, HEB, at a huge discount. I thawed them out the other day and absolutely had to cook them tonight. I didn't quite know what to do with it. It's was a pkg of bone-in chops - thick and thin, boneless chops, pork shoulder steaks, and other cuts I couldn't identify. I came across this recipe and thought I'd give it a shot. I used a beef buillion cube in 12oz of water to simmer them in the crockpot for 4 hours. Then I broke up the meat with my fingers, combined it with half a jar of Nick's BBQ Sauce (great sauce from Carlisle, AK), 1/3c of the simmering liquid, and baked it in a glass dish sprayed with PAM for 30 mins. I just threw it on hamburger buns and it was unbelievably tasty and moist. I can't thank you enough for this quick and easy recipe. I'll be looking for those value packs again. Even now as I type this, hubby is heading back to the kitchen for another sandwich....and he's already had two!

country:
None
text:
Super easy to make & everyone loved it! I quartered a small onion & placed it under the 3lb pork shoulder. I cooked it on high for about 4 hrs, then drained the juice from the crock pot. I shredded the meat with my fingers, just seemed easier than with a fork. I returned the shreaded meat to the crockpot & mixed in two types of BBQ sauce, turned to low heat and left it there for about another hour before finishing it off in the oven for 30 mins. Plan to make it again but instead of using the oven for the last part, I plan to put it on the BBQ grill for 15 mins to get that true smoky flavor.

After reading many of the other reviews I purchased a 5lb pork butt, I rubbed it down with smoked paprika, pepper, lawrys season all,garlic powder, and a little brown sugar. I placed chopped onions in the bottom of the crock pot, and used the beef broth..it took about 5 hours to cook and I mixed 4 bbq sauces together (kraft: hickory smoke, hickory smoke with honey, HOT, and thick and spicy original) it was AMAZING! The 30 minutes in the stove really did it justice! Definitely will be making it again!

text:
I'm not known for being great in the kitchen. I'd never tried anything like this before, so I was wary all afternoon and checked the cooker constantly. No need!  It was tough to shred but came out nice and soft after being in the oven.  Everyone loved this, and I was super excited. I will definitely make this again. Try it out!

Jason

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/486766.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used Pork Spare Ribs.  Doubled the beef broth in the croc pot to ensure the ribs get tender and cooked for 5 hours on high heat.  I found that it was easier to let the ribs cool a bit and then use my fingers to separate the meat from the bones and fat.  I used Sweet Baby Rays (sweet and spicy) BBQ sauce.  Served on buttered and toasted buns.  Very tasty but no better than City BBQ's pulled pork.  Great satisfaction from making my own pulled pork but for the amount of time it took plus the cost of ingredients, I may just buy it from City BBQ by the pound ($11/lb).  1 rack of fibs + Sauce + broth means I saved about $10 over purchasing the same amount from the restuarant.  When I make it next time I'll make a homemade BBQ sauce...I think it would have made all the difference!  Also, to save money, use the leftover beef broth as the base for beef stew for the next evening!

country:
None
text:
Delightful!  I modified slightly to make TexMex carnitas.  I used pork butt instead and coated in salt and pepper before pan searing and putting it in the crockpot with onions and a cup of water. After 6 hours on High in the slowcooker, I removed the pork (so soft) and shredded it with forks and chopped it with kitchen scissors. I took the remaining liquid and reduced it by simmering in a fry pan.  Then I added to the shredded pork and served in small soft taco tortillas with fresh cilantro, diced purple onion, salsa and sour cream.  Tasted amazing and now we have tons of leftovers. And it all came from a $5 piece of meat.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good, especially if you don't have access to a smoker or don't want to keep your oven on for hours. I used bone-in spare ribs - that's all that was left at the grocery store at 5 PM on New Year's Eve - and not such good ones at that :( After a lot of cleaning, (removing fat and silverskin), I cooked them for 4 hrs. in the crockpot with low sodium beef broth, shredded the meat, mixed it with just under an 18 oz bottle of Sweet Baby Rays and finished it in the oven as the recipe stated. It came out hot and a little crusty but still tender (kinda like the crispy "ends" of BBQ, which I prefer. I like a little chew to pulled pork). Served w/cole slaw on hamburger buns, kids loved it, ate two sandwiches each. 10 - 12 servings from 3 lbs of meat will make small sandwiches - take note. I did feed six for about $10, so...that works, eh?

text:
Amazing! I put a whole, bone in, 5 lb pork shoulder (after cutting off a good bit of the fat) into my crockpot at around 11:00 pm last night. At 9:00 am this morning I lifted the bone, and yes, the meat literally slid right off! Shredding the meat was a breeze... I read the reviews about leaving some chunks, but my meat was so tender that just stirring it broke it apart. I used Sweet Baby Rays Hickory Brown Sugar and it is perfect. I skipped the oven step and just let the meat hang out with the sauce in the crock pot. I'm serving this on potato rolls with a dollop of cole slaw on the sandwich. Thank you for an easy and really inexpensive recipe!

userID:

Display Name:
TALCOTT
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I bought 5 lbs. of Country Pork Style Ribs.  It was basically boneless (just 3 or 4 bones total.  I read all reviews and decided to put 2 cans of beef broth, one chopped onion, one chopped green pepper, 5 or 6 chopped garlic cloves.  I cooked for 4 hours.  I took the meat out of the crockpot.  Very easy to take off the few bones I had.  I also was able to cut away the fat easily.  Instead of putting back in the crockpot, I put the shredded pork in a cast iron skilled.  I put a little broth from the crockpot in the skillet plus all of the vegetables (onions, green peppers and garlic) in the skillet.  I used a jar of Stubb's Barbeque Sauce Spicy and a little left over of another sauce.  I blended it with a spoon and put in the oven for 30 minutes on 350 degrees.  This was truly wonderful barbeque.  My husband loved it.  Will definately make this again.  But next time I think I will add a little liquid smoke.

text:
After reading several reviews for not only this recipe, but the other similar recipe on this site using root beer, I decided to attempt making my first crock pot dish. I bought a 5.24 lb Pork shoulder butt. I put about half an onion on the bottom of the crock. I threw the pork on top which i had cut in half to fit in there, and completely covered it in water and two cups of beef broth. I set it on low for 10 hours. Took it out, shredded it, mixed in 28 ounces of Sweet Rays BBQ sauce and threw it in the oven. Served on kaiser rolls. It was sooo delicious even my picky boyfriend said it was "better than restaurant quality."

text:
Made this for the first time for my sons birthday party. It was a HIT! Everyone raved about it and gobbled it up. Whatever was left was taken home as left overs! Easy simple recipe to follow with great results, you can't go wrong. I used pork shoulder with bone in. I cut off the skin and fat from the top, placed it in the slow cooker with the bone. When it was done, the meat fell of the bone, and I shredded it. It was only .79 a pound for the pork shoulder. Ibought 17 lbs and used 2 slow cookers. It was 2 shoulders about 8lbs each.

text:
I, like others, used a 3lb pork butt roast instead of ribs.  Cooked it in the crockpot with the beef broth on high for 4 hours.  Then I turned it down to low for 2 more hours.  So tender I had to remove it from the crockpot with a slotted spoon!  I pulled it apart, emptied the broth from the crockpot.  Then I decided to play with my cheap honey bbq sauce.  I added about 1/4-1/2 cup of cider vinegar to it, to make it taste more like my husband's native North Carolina bbq sauce.  HUGE hit!!!  Hubby and son ate til they were sick, lol!  Will definitely make again!!

text:
I ruined this recipe by putting it in the oven for the last 30 minutes, as stated in directions. Meat became stringy and icky. 

It was perfect before putting it in oven. I cooked on High for 4 hours; turned crockpot off and then had to leave the house unexpectedly. 3 hours later I came home and shredded the meat (which was still hot) It was *PERFECT* at that point so I shouldn't have cooked it in oven. Should've just added BBQ sauce & served right away.

I'm giving it 4 stars since the texture is worse after baking, if you follow the directions.

text:
I am not an expert cook and am constantly trying out new recipes on my fiance. And he LOVED this one and after my first try too. I followed the recipe almost exactly and used the Bullseye Kansas City sauce which had just the right balance of smoky and sweet but did not use the whole bottle. I wanted to make sure the flavor of the pork would still come through. I added my own touch by adding cheese on top of the meat and then low broiling for 2 minutes on top of the hamburger bun and broiled the other half of the bun also...nothing beat the smell of slow cooking pork all afternoon and knowing you'll have leftovers all week.  The leftovers I just added some extra bbq sauce before i microwaved it. Had sides of baked beans and potato salad. Fiance added extra hot sauce to his burger to spice it up.

country:
None
text:
I decided to try this recipe today. although I am partial to the Allrecipe recipe "Slow-Cooked Pork Barbecue," this one is good to. I followed the ingredients and directions, just using low-sodium broth. For some reason though the other recipe reminds me a lot more of a slow cooked smoked pork. It might be the meat cut or the sauce I normally use. This recipe called for 18oz of sauce. There was only one brand in 18oz so I went with it. It was a little more thick, spicy, and sweet than I prefer. I normally use Sauers bbq sauce, which is more of a North Carolina vinegar based sauce. Either way, it was tasty, reheats well, and it made a quick and easy bbq sandwich without a whole lot of work. TY

This was a fabulous recipe. I used boneless ribs, and cooked it for around 6 hours. After shredding the meat, I discarded the broth. Placed the meat back into the cooker and added one bottle of Toms hot barbeque sauce and 1 can of coca cola.

country:
None
text:
This was amazing. I used the boneless pork ribs, like the recipe says, and put them in the crock pot before work with the beef broth. I had it on high for four hours and then on low until I got home. The meat just shredded apart so easily. I then mixed it with 18oz of Sticky Fingers Sweet Carolina BBQ sauce (I added a little more from a second bottle). I put it in the oven to warm it back up and add some crispiness. It was absolutely fantastic! My husband says it was the best pulled pork sandwich he has ever had. I was worried that the 2lbs of meat wouldn't be enough, but it really was. We gorged on it for dinner and then ate it for lunch for the next two days. Easy and yummy recipe! Thanks for posting!

text:
Thanks to ginger, I followed her advice and used a pork butt instead and I cooked it for 10 hours, shredded it and refrigerated overnight and reheated for 2 hours the next day.  
My changes: I used 2 cans of beef broth to cover it better then drained all but about a 1/4 cup of the broth before refrgerating.   The next day I added the bbq sauce (I prefer Maull's sweet & smoky) and also a generous splash of beer.  Turned out great and making it the day before was super easy for entertaining.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/615944.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent! I changed this up a bit because I can't have BBQ sauce due to the tomato. Others I serve this too can have BBQ so I planed to pull out meat for me before adding the BBQ sauce.

Changes:
While in the crockpot I added in one garlic clove, dried parsley, dried cilantro, peppercorn. Cooked it on low for 2 hours and then on high for 4 hours. 

After shredding I put my meat in a skillet and the other meat in another skillet. For both I added a little juice from the crockpot. For mine I added in cayanne pepper and syrup because I love a sweetened pork sandwich! For the other meat added in Bourbon BBQ sauce and a little syrup. Cooked both until most of the juice was gone and the meat had little crispy bits. 

Mine tasted great! I am guessing the other was great as my family didn't even talk while eating and my brother ate his so fast I didn't even see him eat it! My son asked for leftovers the next day.

I goofed on the recipe (forgot the broth, just covered in bbq sauce and cooked all day). I should have looked over it again before making this dish; but it still turned out good. It still would have been better had I turned the crockpot off after about 8 hours, before the bbq sauce burned. Even still, it is still good and I have a TON. Used a pork shoulder roast. I'll put quite a bit of it back to use in bbq beans,etc. Great recipe. I can't wait to try it the right way. Super easy and delish!

text:
The recipe was overall very easy to follow with three main ingredient. This definitely has room to grow with, allowing one to tweak it to their taste buds. We added onion powder and garlic salt for seasoning. My husband added some apple juice to the broth to help tenderize and flavor the meat. Could use more sauce and flavoring, but that is something that can easily be adjusted, so we will definitely make this recipe again. Will be keeping this in the recipe box.

2/1/13
We made this recipe many times since our first try. It is definitely worth 5 stars for how easy it is. And we found using country style boneless ribs to be the best for this recipe. I tried doing different seasonings and found one that works best for our family. Oh, and apple vinegar is much better than apple juice.  I originally rated this 4 stars and changed it to 5 because it wasn't the recipes fault that I felt it needed more flavor and sauce.  So after tweaking it up a bit to our liking we think it taste better than any restaurants pull pork we ever had.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1983377.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
so...i asked my butcher if i could use a pork tenderloin to make this because i hate fatty meat.  she said "absolutely not, it would be rubbery".  so, i decided that i would try it anyway.  i did not really follow this recipe because i think that just beef broth was not enough flavoring.  i put the pork tenderloins in my crockpot (about 2.5 pounds), added 3 T. liquid smoke, 1/4 cup brown sugar, 1 tsp. salt, 1/2 tsp. black pepper, 3 large cloves garlic, minced, and 1 onion, finely chopped.  I poured that all over the pork, then i added just enough beef broth to cover the bottom.  i cooked it on high for 4 1/2 hours.  IT WAS WONDERFUL!  Tender, moist, shredded right apart with two forks, not rubbery at all, and HEALTHIER!  I made my own BBQ sauce and added it to the mixture.  DELISH!!!!

text:
WARNING: Be sure to DRAIN the beef before adding the BBQ sauce.  The first time I wasn't paying attention and I accidentally added the BBQ sauce and it was (obviously) super watery.  Second time I made this I drained the beef, but I still felt like it wasn't enough and when I froze/thawed it out the beef was still in a watery bbq-sauce.  Short of patting the  beef dry (which I'll probably do on my third attempt), I would recommend drying out your crockpot before putting the beef back in, then adding the BBQ sauce.

text:
This recipe is bone-head simple and SO delicious!   I made this for Christmas dinner (along with a beef brisket and cheesy potatoes - yum!).  My brother walked in my house and said, "It smells like pulled pork!" and then proceeded to sit down and eat seconds, thirds, fourths of it until all platters were empty.  He wasn't the only one to get a second helping, either.  And my aunt has asked me for "my" recipe.  :)  Slight changes:  I use bullion & water instead of canned broth - because that is what we have on hand.  I used a pork shoulder instead of ribs because it was what I found, and very affordable.  And since I have neither a dutch oven or iron skillet, I simply put the meat on a baking tray when it comes to the oven step.  I've made this recipe twice already with excellent results.  Try it for yourself, you won't be disappointed!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I used a 7 lb pork butt.  I first cut all visible fat and then. cooked it on high in the crock for about 8 hours.  In the crock I put a layer of sliced onion rings on the bottom, then the pork, then I used a few dashes of worshteshire sauce, liquid smoke, and a tsp. of minced garlic.  Poured 16 oz. of low salt beef broth over it.  I used Sweet Baby Ray's bbq sauce but my advice to you is to use whatever bbq sauce you enjoy.  After removing, I shredded it and removed any visible fat I saw that remained, no big deal and easy to do.   I do believe the oven step is important to give a little browning to the beef which greatly adds to the texture.  This is EXCELLENT bbq pork and makes a generous amount, would be great for tailgates or parties.  I will no longer be buying it already made at my local butcher for $10/lb!  I have been looking for a recipe like this for ages, thanks so much!

text:
This was great!  Please take the time to put the pork in the oven with the sauce as this allows the sauce to almost caramelize and really soak into the meat.  I found that my meat needed 10 hours in the crock pot (I used a 4lb shoulder roast) but I didn't have 10 hours so when I found it wasn't done at 8 hours I simmered it on the stove top for about 40 min and it was perfectly tender but not mushy.  Something to add:  I put a layer of thickly sliced onions on the bottom of the crock just for flavor and to keep the meat from sticking to the bottom. I also think I will leave out the broth next time and just use water and season my meat!  So good and cheap!

text:
I modified some parts of this recipe for a quicker meal and less dishes. First I purchased pork butt for the recipe instead of the chops. With the economy nowadays I need to pinch every penny I have. I trimmed about 75% of the fat off of the meat before putting it in the slow cooker with the beef broth. I added a dash of brown sugar (just a tiny amount..it makes the meat even more tender and sweet). After cooking about four hours on low I removed the meat and shredded it. I emptied to crock pot of juices and put meat back in crock. I added Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce, Bullseye BBQ sauce, and some Frank's red hot sauce.

The end product was amazing. I just finished my meal and ate way too much but it felt so good! This will become a regular in my meals!

text:
This was delicious!! We used almost 9 pounds of boneless pork tenderloin. We sliced an onion on the bottom of the crockpot, then slit the meat and put whole cloves of garlic throughout the meat for extra flavor. We put one more onion sliced on the top of the meat and then poured 2 cups of beef broth over. Then we covered and let it cook on high for 1 hour and a half and then rest on 7 hours on low. We used Sweet Baby Ray's sauce of course which made it absolutely delicious. Served with baked beans and corn on the cob. Perfect meal which was greatly enjoyed by everyone.. and plenty of leftovers for at least 2 different nights for 5 adults.

This recipe was perfect!  That said, I altered it a little according to the reviews I read before starting.  First off, I coarsly chopped an onion and added it and a peeled clove of garlic to the beef broth.  I used pork shoulder, and used a pork rub on it before putting it together.  It cooked on high for about an hour, then on low for another 5-6 hours, and the meat was falling off the bone.  If it wasn't hot, I wouldn't have needed forks to shred it.  I used a doctored-up barbeque sauce, adding a little vinager and whatever else I had lying around that sounded good.  Overall, a fantastic recipe - definitely one I'll keep around and do again frequently.  Thank you!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe. I'm from the south, but now live in the north, and every now and then I get a craving for BBQ pork sandwiches... but have noticed the north lacks the BBQ restaurants so prevalent in the south. This recipe tastes a lot like the sandwiches from a restaurant I used to visit in the south. I used 4.5 pounds of boneless pork ribs, but only used one 18 ounce bottle of Kraft Original BBQ sauce. I also mixed in some of the leftover beef broth to make it a little more moist, and let the mixture heat up in the slow cooker rather than in the oven. I'm not a huge fan of BBQ sauce, so I think the 18 ounce bottle to only 3 pounds would have been way too much for my tastes. One bottle to 4.5 pounds had just a hint of BBQ flavoring that wasn't too little or too overpowering. I noticed everyone here is using Sweet Baby Ray's, but I thought the Kraft tasted just fine (I would imagine if you like a lot of BBQ sauce, then the brand/taste would matter more.) If you're like me, I'd recommend adding the sauce a little at a time and taste testing rather than dumping the entire bottle in.

text:
This is awesome.  I used boneless pork ribs.  The only thing I did different, was to sprinkle meat with garlic powder added diced green pepper and 1 medium onion. Let the meat cook in the slow cooker for four hours on high, drained juice, reserving 1/2 cup otherwise it comes out to runny.  Shredded pork and added it along with the peppers and onions back to crockpot with reserved juice, 1 1/2 bottles of Famous Daves bold barbeque sauce and let cook for another two hours on low to blend flavors. Make sure you stir every 20 to 30 minutes after adding the sauce so it don't burn.  My co-workers loved it and you have less dishes to clean up. Thanks for the post, this is great.

This was awesome!  I made this on Saturday for dinner.  I put the roast (pork picnic shoulder) in the crock pot at 8am on low.  At 4pm, I drained the liquid, shredded the pork with 2 foks (it came apart very easily) and put it back on the crock pot on Warm for another hour with some more bbq sauce only.  Served on Kaisers with fries.  FANTASTIC!!  Will definitely make this again.  My boyfriend loved it.  The meat almost melted in your mouth, it was so tender!  Thank you KK!

text:
One of the easiest and best recipes in my collection, and so delicious that I will search no more for a bbq pork recipe.  It's very versatile and can be adapted to your personal taste just by the sauce you choose to use.  I was pressed for time, so I cooked/shredded it one night, and baked it with the sauce the next.  Thanks for sharing what will become a standard dish in our house!

text:
This was amazing!  I used a boston butt roast, chicken stock, water, and onion.  Once meat was done, I took it out of the slow cooker, pulled it, poured the sauce over it, and finished it in the oven like the recipe recommended.  It is tempting to just add sauce to the slow cooker, but let me tell you, like many of the other reviewers, baking it makes it so much better!  Don't skip this step, it is worth washing another pan!

I combined some other reviews. I used pork shoulder for a cheaper cut and cooked it for 11 hours on low with a bottle of beer instead of broth. Then shredded and mixed with BBQ sauce. Next day, put it back in the slow cooker til noon. Everyone gobbled it down on toasted buns with chips and fruit. Not my favorite slow cooked pork but definitely the easiest and plenty good.

text:
This is really simple and easy to do.

I would say to leave the pork in the crock pot for at least 7hrs. I used 3lb. pork shoulder before and around 7hrs it was still stringy, but you were able to pull it apart. 

I tried it again, but left the pork in for 9hrs and it was perfect. Very soft and tender when it came out.

Can't go wrong with this recipe!

city:

country:
None
text:
This is a good recipe, but try making your own barbq sauce with Root Beer or Cola.

Cook your pork in 1/2 c. rootbeer or cola in the slow cooker til it falls apart.   while that is cooking, in saucepan, pour one can rootbeer, bottle of chili sauce, and simmer covered for 30 minutes.  take off lid and cook longer to reduce, if you want it thicker. 

Once your pork is done in the slow cooker, shred and put the pork in the sauce and let it sit to absorb more flavor.  yummy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use 3 lbs. boneless country ribs with a cup or so of broth in slow cooker. Usually put on at night before bed and in the a.m. (10-12 hours) I let cool and shred.  I add 1 1/2 bottles of Sweet Baby Ray's Honey BBQ sauce and a little of the broth and mix well and put in a 9x13 pan. I leave in the fridge all day while at work and then bake at 350 degrees for 45 minutes, stirring every once in awhile. I prefer serving on potato buns, but is delicious no matter what-even not on a bun!  Except for removing the fat and shredding it couldn't be easier or more delicious!

text:
Made this for our safari birthday party (except we called it BBQ'd Water Buffalo!). It was awesome.  We bought 3 huge pork butts, cheaper cut, took a while cutting some fat off of them, threw them in the crock pot with beef broth (bouillon cube style), shredded with forks, drained the broth off put it in the fridge, reheated it the day of the party (putting sauce on right before people got there) and people cleaned this stuff up.  About 5 or 6 people asked me how to make it. Used Super Smokers sauce (original recipe), everyone loved it.

text:
after reading the reviews n seeing the popularity of this dish, i thot it wld really b super awesome. well, it wasn't bad, but neither did it deserve such rave reviews i think. actually i didn't really understand y i had to cook in beef broth, because as it turned out, after cooking the pork overnight in beef broth, and aft smothering all the bbq sauce on the meat, i cld only taste the bbq sauce with pork. there was no hint of beef on the meat at all. in essence, i cld hv jus boiled the meat in water until its soft enough to be shredded and then smother the bbq sauce on it...i don't think there's gonna b much of a diff in taste. overall, not a super great recipe, but not that bad so just 3 stars fm me!

text:
I made it similar to the suggested method, but cooked it much longer in the slow cooker.  I think it was in for 12 hours under beef broth then another 5 hours only 1/2 submerged in the broth.  

It turned out so good that I think I will never purchase a pork BBQ sandwich at the fairs again.  This was much better.  

I mixed the BBQ with the "big al's kc bar-b-q sauce" recipe from here on AR.  Try it all together and you will be amazed.

text:
I just made couple changes the first time I made this. I bought a 3 lb. pork loin (bone in) because there are only two of us.  I cooked it on high for 4 hours and then on low for 3. When I switched it to low I added one packet of onion soup mix, started to shred the pork and flipped it over so the top wouldn't dry out. Then when it was done in the slow cooker I finished shredding it and put it in the dutch oven. I saved some of the juice from the crockpot and put it in the bottom of the dutch oven because I was worried about it drying out in the 30 minutes, added my pork and one bottle of Sweet baby rays. Turned out perfect and juicy!!

This was fantastic!  I used a 3 lb boneless pork roast instead and cooked it in the beef broth for 4 hours, then let sit in the fridge overnight.  I put it back on high in the morning for 1 hour, then removed the roast and dumped out the liquid.  I shredded the meat, put back in the crockpot, then added 2 bottles of Sweet Baby Ray's Honey Chitpotle barbecue sauce and turned it on low until heated through.  I served on mini asiago cheese rolls.  The kids loved it!  Will definately be making again.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Used pork butt roast and slow cooked thru the night before, and put it in the fridge before leaving for work.  When I got home, I skimmed the fat, and removed the larger pieces of fat from the roast.  They came off eailsy, in big chunks.  I Turned he cooker on high, and let it cook for an hour or so.  After pulling the roast apart with 2 forks, I added enough room-temp Stubbs BBQ sauce to make it nice and saucey.  Skipped the oven, served on potato rolls with coleslaw.  Perf!

text:
This was good and simple. Tip: If you want to make it for two, you need only 1lb. of pork, and even that leaves leftovers. The pork will cook in about two hours instead of 4. Also, be choosy about the type of BBQ sauch you use. It's really the main taste of this dish so you should be aware of which you prefer; hickory, honey, etc. Great recipe.

text:
This recipe is great, but I had a bit of a disaster with it, as I bought 3 lbs. of ribs with the bone in.  By the time it comes to adding the bbq sauce, they're super juicy, and the bbq sauce doesn't stick at all to the meat, which you have to eat off the bone or spend too long cutting it off.  Not the same.  Be sure to use BONELESS ribs, so that the meat can shred like it should, and not be so juicy that all the flavorful drippings slide right off!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This was amazing and will be a regular recipe for family meals! All my store had was bone-in pork shoulder butt which worked extremely well. I added a few shakes of liquid smoke into the beef broth. It ended up cooking on high for about 10 hours before it was done. I removed the meat (no juices) from the crockpot and put it in the fridge overnight. About noon the next day I took it out, shredded the meat with my fingers, added 3 bottles BBQ sauce (it was a lot of meat!) and a few more shakes of liquid smoke. I cooked it on low in the crockpot with the lid OFF until dinner time. It had a great texture (not mushy) and a great smoky BBQ flavor.

Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! Was this ever yummy!!! Made BBQ pork sandwiches for dinner Wed. night. I put everything (i.e. 3.5 lb. "family size" pkg. of pork shoulder / western style ribs & a 14 oz. can beef broth) in my slow cooker around 10 AM and set to cook on LOW for 9 hrs. When I got home around 2:30, my sc was off (argh!)!!! Since the meat was hot to the touch, I figured it couldn't have been off for too long.... Unsure of whether that was the case or not, I re-programmed my sc to cook on HIGH for another 4 hrs. As a result, my meat was tender and VERY easy to shred. I did as KMB233 recommended and baked my pork in a 350 degree oven for 30 min. My bf & I found the meat to be a tad dry, so I suggest anyone using the oven to reduce the baking time to 15-20 min. MAX. Having said that, I DO think this step is critical in order to get that "from the grill" texture as SKANDREWS mentioned - simmering in a sc is "OK," but won't yield the same end result. The same goes for the BBQ sauce you use (I suggest a VERY good quality store-bought sauce or your favorite homemade recipe). I used Sweet Baby Ray's hickory & brown sugar sauce which was ABSOLUTELY delicious. Served "generous" helpings on sesame sandwich buns w/ Restaurant-Style Coleslaw I by Marsha, BBQ kettle chips and a my last 2 bottles of Goose Island orange cream soda to wash it all down! Thx. for sharing :)

text:
This recipe is by far the best one and the easiest one. Like many of the others I used a Boson Butt. It's much cheaper and extremely flavorful. I threw a 6-7 lb. butt in the crock pot with 2 cans of beef broth early evening and by morning (12 hrs later) it was done. The meat was so moist and tender it was already off the bone. What's so nice about this recipe is you can use whatever sauce you would like as there are so many different kinds of bbq sauces out there. I have made this recipe 3 times in the last several months and everyone just loves it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pork is absolutely delicious. I've done it twice now, once with a rolled pork butt, and once with shoulder chops. Both worked well - the shoulder chops were a bit easier because they had much less fat, but they were more expensive, too. Either works great. I really don't think there's a cut of pork that wouldn't work.  In the slow cooker, I used beef broth once, and beer once, and both were great.   For the baking step I used plain ol' Heinz Sweet and Spicy BBQ sauce, in a cast iron pan in the oven for 30-40 minutes. I can't recommend highly enough to not skip this step - it really seals in the flavour and makes for some dark, crunchy, baked bits. Gives more texture and much better flavour.   This recipe rules. I found it pretty messy on a bun, so I ate it wrapped up in tortillas with coleslaw. Faaaaaantastic.

text:
This was the easiest, best BBQ I have ever made.  I was tempted to throw in an onion, because I was afraid it would not have enough flavor.  However, I decided not to and didn't miss it at all.  It was very flavorful.  I made it in the Crock Pot, just cooked it on low for 6-8 hours, drained the juice, added BBQ sauce and let it sit on "warm" for an hour or two.  We had nothing left over and I can't wait to make it again.

text:
Delicious! However, I do highly recommend using beef bouillon instead of broth. I didn't have beef broth one time that I made this, so I substituted bouillon granules. It came out incredibly, and better than the times I used broth (which was still really good). I highly recommend pairing this recipe with the recipe for "Big Al's K.C. Bar-B-Q Sauce" found here. It is well worth the time to make this sauce. The two combined taste like restaurant pulled BBQ. (I halved the sauce recipe, and had plenty for 4 lbs of pork.)

country:
None
text:
This recipe is simple and awesome. My wife and I received our Hamilton Beach slow cooker (with interchangeable 2, 4 & 6 quart crocks) the other day and this was the first recipe we tried with it. Nancy picked up a 5lb pork butt from our local Genuardi's supermarket, and had the butcher remove the bone (he also trimmed the fat!). We used the 6 quart crock. Started at 8PM. Put 2 cans of broth in just to be safe (but after cooking realised 1 was enough) and then put in the 5lb slab of pork. Set it on low, and this morning at 6:15AM got up and it was so tender it shredded so easily! I didn't put it in the oven to do the final step. Just poured 1 bottle of BBQ sauce over half that we shredded, and froze the other non-shredded half. For 3 of us (my wife and our 1 yr old son) 5 lbs is going to go a long way! I know we're going to love this, haven't tried it yet, but will be enjoyng it at lunch for the next few days I can guarantee!

text:
This recipe got emailed to me and so I decided to try it. I had a bunch of boneless pork chops in my freezer, so I decided to use those. I only had 1 can of beef broth on hand, and after reading the reviews wanted to make sure it didn't get dried out. So I decided to use a bottle of beer (like another reviewer had done) with the beef broth. I cooked it on low for 7 hours. It shredded very easily. I baked in a glass baking dish with a cover using Sweet Baby Rays. I put them on Hawaiian rolls that I grilled with a little margarine (IN-N-OUT style). I had seen them done like this as sliders at Ruby's Restaurant. Very delicious. Even my picky kids ate 3 of them!!

text:
Wow...so easy and so good! I had a family pack of 7 Bone In Chops, but there is only 3 of us, so thought this was a good idea to use the whole pack at once. I put one can of broth in the crock. Sprinkled each chop, both sides, with Bad Byron's Butt Rub. (Can be found at some Kroger Stores.) Put it on low at 7 am, then at 7:30 pm, I used tongs to pull the chops and bones out into a pan lined with foil. The chops were so tender, I didn't even have to shred....just fell apart as I tried to lift it out of the crock! A local BBQ joint, Hog Wild, sells their BBQ Sauce in squeeze bottles, so I squeezed about 3/4 bottle onto the shredded pork, stuck it in the oven, and OH MY! The pork was good before I even put the sauce on it! We have enough left, I plan to use the rest tomorrow for Pulled Pork Fajitas!

text:
This is SO EASY!  You can use roast instead of ribs.  Put the roast and broth in the crock pot for about 6-8 hours.  Then take the meat out and shred it with a fork.  Add your favorite bottled sauce and put it in the oven for about 30 minutes.  This is perfect if you know you're going to have a busy day and won't want to cook dinner later.  Just buy some baked beans and potato salad or chips and you have an easy dinner!

This was amazing! I was a little skeptical before making this recipe since it was so easy and I was afraid that it was "too good to be true". It turned out great! text:
EXCELLENT! I WAS RAISED IN THE SOUTH ON PORK BBQ & MY HUSBAND WAS INTRODUCED TO PORK BBQ IN THE LAST FEW YEARS(IN TEXAS BBQ IS BEEF, NOT PORK). WE BOTH ENJOYED THIS DISH. HE REALLY LOVED IT. ALTHOUGH IT IS NOT JUST LIKE MEMPHIS-STYLE PORK BBQ, IT IS EXTREMELY CLOSE! I USED A PORK SHOULDER ROAST WITH BONE (COULDN'T FIND BONELESS) AND COOKED IT FOR 6 HRS IN THE CROCKPOT. I TOOK PREVIOUS ADVICE AND TORE IT INTO CHUNKS (INSTEAD OF SHREDDING IT). IT JUST FELL OFF THE BONE. THEN I RETURNED IT TO THE CROCKPOT WITH 4T OF THE BROTH AND A BOTTLE OF SWEET BABY RAY'S SAUCE FOR AN HOUR. IT REALLY TURNED OUT DELICIOUS. THIS WILL DEFINITELY BE A FAMILY FAVORITE. I LOOK FORWARD TO SERVING THIS TO A LARGE PARTY OF GUESTS THIS SUMMER- IT WAS VERY VERY EASY TO MAKE.

text:
This was really good! I used a pork rub on a 4.5 lb pork butt the night before & cooked in 2 cups beef broth for 6 hrs on high. Very little shredding was needed, it pretty much fell apart. I drained the broth, reserving about 4 tbs, which I put back in the crockpot with the meat & BBQ sauce. I turned the crockpot back on for about an hour to warm up sauce. Yum! Served on toasted rolls - - 3 guy-friends tried it and all loved it! Thanks for the recipe!!!!

text:
Thank you for this simple and great recipe.  I modified a few ingredients personally.  I used Pork Sirloin Tip Roast from Costco (very cheap $) and K.C. Masterpiece BBQ Sauce.  I used 2 cups of boiling water and 2 beef bullion cubes in place of the canned broth.  Finally, I made a dry rub from combining grill mates BBQ seasoning, Montréal steak seasoning, and garlic powder which I rubbed in really good before setting into the crock put/broth.  4 hours on high made it shred perfectly by stirring it with a fork (just like the recipe) and then like other reviewers I just drained the excess broth, put the BBQ sauce right in the crock pot, and set it to low for 30 minutes.  Perfecto!  This is an awesome recipe, and tastes great!  Use your favorite BBQ sauce, and next time I am going to experiment with adding smoke flavors and hot sauce =)  Thanks!

country:
None
text:
Tender and delicious! I doubled the recipe, using two 4-lb. pork shoulders (considering fat content and a little bone). I trimmed as much visible fat as I could before slow-cooking, and only used one can of broth. It worked great to put it on at bedtime. In the morning, I shredded it, rinsed the meat lightly with hot water to remove excess fat, and then added the BBQ sauce. It almost filled a 9"x13" pan and made 5 lbs. of meat w/sauce. Not counting the slow-cooking, it took less than 45 minutes to shred and prepare. I refrigerated it, then reheated the meat before serving later that day. Great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE THIS!! It's such a great, quick, simple recipe. I usually use a really cheap roast, around the 2½ - 3 pound range, instead of ribs. I also use a higher quality BBQ sauce than I use when grilling (I've tried Kraft sauces, and they just don't do the recipe justice.. Cattlemen's and Bullseye sauces are a lot better). Once the meat is cooked, I remove it from the cooker, empty the cooker of the broth, shred the meat, and then I put the meat BACK in the cooker with the BBQ sauce. I let it heat up for maybe another 45 minutes or an hour on high (check it after a while, and see if it's heating well), and it's good to go. Excellent with fries or chips and some salad. Thanks KK!!
