text:
I have tried many recipes and this is the first I am rating.  This was fantastic!  I made is for my sons birthday party and everyone loved it!  I made about 15lbs of ribs (using mostly trimmed boneless country style) the night before, cooking for 8 hours on low.  After shredding, I put it in a large tupperware bowl, added 3 ladels full of the broth and 3 bottles of bbq sauce.  I shook it until it was kind of blended and let it sit overnight.  I put it back in the crockpot the next morning and let it heat on low for about 4 hours.
I will be making this again and again and again!

text:
I don't have a butcher, I have a walmart. That's the type of city I live in so I make do. I couldn't find a cut of butt under 5 lbs, and it being just me at home (meal planning for the next week or so) I got another type of roast in 3 lbs. Cooked it according to the recipe, except the skillet / oven part, put it back into the slower cooker for that part, on high for one hour to two hours with bbq sauce and some of cooking liquid. Cook until liquid cooks down and thickens and pork starts to brown on the bottom. 18 oz is NO WHERE near enough sauce for this recipe. Went out to get another bottle.  Without the other bottle it's good, with the extra it's better though.  I do want to try this with a homemade bbq recipe though. Sweet baby rays is amazeballs, but I bet the spices come through stronger and more complex when it's fresh.

text:
I followed what other reviewers said and used a less expensive cut of meat (pork shoulder butt).  Put it in the slow cooker for 9+ hours and thought that may have been a little long because when I used two forks to shred (which was really easy, by the way), I felt like the meat was a little too overworked.  Did it the day before, added bbq sauce and put in fridge.  The day of the party I pulled it out a few hours ahead of time to reheat but ended up zapping in the microwave because it wasn't heating fast enough and guests were on their way.  Still, everyone (and I mean everyone) raved about it!!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-07-12T10:45:21.127
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
3804983
Display Name:
Vicky Ferrell Field
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
149
favoritesCount:
414
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2618091.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for our 4th of July cookout and it was amazing.  I did two 5 lb pork butts in two separate crockpots.  I cooked them on high for 5 1/2 hours due to the bigger size but kept the beef broth to one can in each pot.  I shredded one by hand with two forks (took about 15 minutes), and the other one went into the food processor on shred (took about 30 seconds). Shredding one of the roasts in the food processor was a HUGE time saver, however, I would not recommend doing this for the entirety of the recipe though because it is a much finer chop and would probably taste very mushy without the larger hand shredded pieces to balance it out.  I then mixed both the chopped and shredded meat  together and returned them to the crockpot.  The meat fit into one crockpot once all the fat and bones were removed.  I stirred in 2 bottles of Sweet Baby Ray's Sweet and Spicy and One bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's Original.  I set the crockpot on warm and left it in for the entirety of the cookout.  The meat went back into the crockpot at about 5 pm and stayed on the warm setting unil about 1 am.  No mushiness whatsoever.  This made TONS of barbecue so we were able to enjoy leftovers the next day and they were still fabulous!.  This recipe will DEFINITELY be a fixture at all our regular summer get togethers!

text:
I used a 3.5 lb pork butt. I cooked it in my slow cooker for 4 hrs. I drained the broth and shredded the pork. I added the pork back into my slow cooker with approximately 1.5 cups of bbq sauce. I set the slow cooker on warm and warmed it up for 30 minutes then served. The pork was cooked perfectly. I added more bbq sauce on the pork sandwiches so everyone could have their choice of hot bbq sauce, mild bbq sauce or honey bbq sauce. For how easy this recipe is to make and the few ingredients required to make it, this really is a great recipe. A keeper! Especially for the nights I don't feel like cooking! Great leftovers too!

text:
SOOOOOO Mouthwateringly good!!! I used a  3.5lb pork shoulder, (pork Butt)  and 1 can of beef broth. Set it on low for 8 hrs in the crockpot and it was done! Shredding it was so easy, it literally fell apart to the touch. Just took out the bone and fat and it was amazing with the Baby Rays BBQ sauce. Also added about a 1/2 cup of remaining broth. (Extra tip: I strained the liquid and had amazing pork broth. Used it to make split pea soup! Best I ever made. Its a huge difference from using the chicken or vegetable broth. Has that really authentic pork flavor.)

userID:
101039
Display Name:
MSMORGAN
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like many other reviewers here, I used a boston butt instead of the boneless ribs. I soaked the meat in a brine solution overnight, then put a generous amount of dry rub on it before putting it in the crock pot. I also cut up an onion in thick slices and placed in the bottom of the crock. I placed the meat in fat side up. After cooking it on low for about 10 hours, I removed the bone (came out effortlessly!), let the crock cool and then placed the whole thing in the fridge. The next morning, I removed the cold fat off the top of the crock, then pulled the fat off the meat. I used forks to shred the meat, then added the sauce. Covered the pan with aluminum foil, placed in oven at 350 degrees to reheat. Made the sides while it reheated (used the leftover broth to cook rice in), family said it was the best bbq'd pork they've ever had. Since then, I have made the recipe as written, with soaking meat in brine the night before as the only adjustment. Just as good! Even though I followed the suggestions of others originally, with a few changes of my own, I still think this is the best pork recipe on the entire site. This one is definitely a keeper!!!

Absolutely THE BEST pulled pork I've ever had!  I've taken this pork to a birthday party and a family reunion, and I get rave reviews every time.  I never go home with much, even though I always double the recipe for company.  The only reason I give this 4 stars instead of 5 is because I've been having a hard time choosing a barbecue sauce. Jack Daniels was a little too salty.

text:
I don't think I've ever made such a great meal that took so little effort, I almost had to laugh at how easy it is.  When I took the meat out of the slow cooker it was already shredding on its own, it was so tender.  I followed this recipe exactly except I added one thing....I put a baster full of the juice/broth into the empty barbecue sauce bottle, shook it up and emptied it into the meat and stirred it in before baking in the oven.  It just seemed a touch dry and I didn't have more bbq sauce to add.  Turned out fabulous.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out really great! My husband has been really wanting me to make pulled pork for the longest time and I have been hesitant to try, but this recipe ended up making it much much easier than I expected. I followed the advice of some other reviewers and bought a pork roast (about 4lbs) I put in in the crock pot with a bottle of beer and about 2 cups of beef broth. I cooked it four about 5.5 hours (looking back, that was probably a about 1 hour too long). Then, I removed the roast, transferred it to a large glass baking dish and shredded it. Then I mixed in a 32 oz bottle of BBQ sauce (smoky-sweet worked great!) and put it in a 375 degree oven for about 15-20 minutes. IT WAS GREAT!! My husband loved it. And it made plenty, enough for several meals. The only thing I wished was that the meat was slightly more tender and juicy. It may have been the cut, or that I let it cook too long, as mentioned previously, but regardless it was great and I will be doing it again soon.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/527614.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is perfect. The only thing I changed was added half a can of broth, and half a bottle of BBQ sauce in the Crock Pot so it would cook with the BBQ sauce flavor. The Pork was ready after 6 hours. (I used a nice pork roast) I moved it to a baking pan and shredded all of it, then added the rest of the BBQ sauce, stirred it all up and baked at 350 for 30 minutes. NOTE: Whenever I use bottled BBQ sauce, I always add to it, as it never seems tasty enough for me. I pour it into a bowl, then add a little of each until I'm happy with the results: cayenne pepper, hot sauce (Tapatio, Chalula, or Tabasco) garlic salt, crushed peppers (like the kind you get with pizza) Worcestershire sauce, and black pepper and whatever else you like to taste in your BBQ sauce. You also could add some beer, Whiskey, Bourbon, etc....

Made to serve at a party and got rave reviews!  Used 6lbs boneless ribs, 2 cans of beef broth and Sweet Baby Rays BBQ Sauce.  Followed others suggestions and added sliced onion to the bottom of the crockpot.  Seasoned ribs with salt, pepper, garlic powder, and chili powder.  Cooked on high for 7ish hours. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was like real barbecue. Even my nephew who works in a BBQ restaurant went back for seconds!

I used a 2.5 lb boneless Boston Butt (pork shoulder). I would say that the 2.5 lb Boston Butt made about 5-6 sandwiches. 

I seasoned it with pepper and Lawry's seasoning salt, then browned all the sides in a pan. I put an onion, cut into big chunks, in the bottom of the crock pot and a can of low sodium beef broth, then put the meat on top. I let it run on LOW for 8 hours, and it was perfect. I just unplugged the crock pot when it was done and let it sit in there for 6 hours until I was ready to do the remaining steps. 

The pork looked good when it was pulled and had the barbecue sauce mixed in. It looked even better after it came out of the oven. I used Sweet Baby Ray's Honey Barbecue sauce (the whole bottle) and added some Cattleman's Memphis Sweet bbq sauce. 

This was a very easy meal for a party--make the pork, buy sandwich buns and potato salad, open up a can of beans, buy chips and veggies with dip, pickles, onions, and extra bbq sauce, and you're set.

text:
Is this an innovative recipe? No.  Does it depend mainly on the type of BBQ sauce? Of course, there are only 3 ingredients!  Yet, it still deserves 5 stars. Why?  Because it is simple, cheap, and tasty!  Took past suggestions and cooked pork/broth in crock pot (low) for 7hr, added BBQ (Jack Daniel's Honey Smokehouse) and put in fridge for about 7hr, then added lit more BBQ than recipe called for (when I tasted it it was a bit light) & warmed up in crockpot for about 3hrs (2high, 1warm). Will mention that I am not sure if cooking it this way improved it from the stated directions but what I do know was it was very tasty.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent! I may have done it a little different but it worked. I put a sirloin pork roast in the crock pot with chicken stock and half an onion chopped up. When I got home I shredded the pork, put it in a roasting pan and drizzled the juices from the pan over it. I then mixed in this great BBQ sauce recipe (that I received from the ratings reviews) over it:    The recipe i used for the sauce is: 1/2 cup cider vinegar 1/2 cup packed brown sugar 1/2 cup ketchup 1/4 cup chili sauce 1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce 2 tbsp chopped onions 1 tbsp lemon juice 1/2 tsp ground mustard 1 clove garlic, minced dash cayenne pepper Combine all sauce ingredients in a saucepan. Simmer, uncovered, for 1 hour or until slightly thickened, stirring occasionally. The only tweak I did to it was double the vinegar part.  I baked the shredded, BBQ sauce drenched meat for an hour to 'crisp the edges' and forced my guests to add coleslaw to the sammich and it was a hit!  Thanks!

It was really good!! I made a few changes to suit mine and my family's tastes. I added 1/4 cup of onions in with the beef broth. Then I added a dry rub of McCormick Slow Cooker Pulled Pork Seasoning with 4 Tablespoons of brown sugar mixed in. city:

region:

country:
None
text:
My hard to please son and 8 others enjoyed this.  Some went back for seconds without the bread.  I used an inexpensive 3.75 lb. pork butt, garlic and 1 cup of broth which was plenty.  I could probably just use 1/2 cup or even water.  For a mixed age group, I needed 6oz. of raw pork butt/person.  I used a great, Hawaiian-style sauce Kona Coast Tropical Sweet 'n Spicy.  Cook it on low for 8 hours at which time it will shred easily.  Drain most if not all of the liquid and save it as stock.  Add some sauce and oven cook it to dry it  for sandwiches so the bread doesn't get soggy.  Serve some sauce on the side for those who want extra!

text:
The most delicious pulled pork ever!  I too recommend, as others have so helpfully, the pork butt cut (cheaper and so perfect) and to cook longer if you can. I like Cattleman's original with some added honey.  Yum!

text:
Read all the reviews and helpful hints... combined what I thought were the best of the best... and voila... wonderful, tender pulled pork which easily tasted just like my favorite restaurant.  I didn't have a can of beef broth, so I used Lipton's  Beefy Onion Soup Mix and one cup of water.  I used a 2 pound pork shoulder roast which I sliced into 1" thick slabs. and cooked them on my crock pot's high setting.  After five hours it was very tender. All I had to do was shredd the meat and add barbecue sauce.  I used Sweet Baby Rays which is dee-licous.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/396924.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took the advice of others and we bought a really inexpensive roast. It was 3lbs and about $3.50 and it was a butt roast. Instead of putting it in the crockpot on high, I started it in the morning and put it on low for 8 hours. Usually when you do this the meat falls apart a LOT easier than if you were to cook it fast on high. We used Cattleman's BBQ and my husband RAVED about them. I really enjoyed these too. So simple! We only put them in the oven for 10 minutes instead of 30 for fear it would dry out the roast.

text:
You will love this recipe!  I throw my ribs on the grill for about 5 minutes per side for a smoky flavor and then throw in the crockpot.  I also use the beer instead of beef broth while cooking.  You might want to brush/spray a little olive oil on the ribs before throwing on the grill b/c they are fairly dry.  I do once a month cooking, and I have incorporated this recipe into my freezer cooking.  I freeze the meat/sauce mixture and reheat portions later!  Yum!

text:
I know a 1 star rating is not the typical reaction to this recipe, however, I did not like it. My boyfriend LOVED this meal and if he was rating this recipe, he would give it 5 stars. We doubled the recipe, so we used 6 lbs. of boneless western style pork ribs , 2 cans of beef broth, and a mixture of 3 different bbq sauces (Sweet Baby Ray: Honey, Open Pit: Original, and Kraft: Thick N' Spicy). We took the meat out of the slow cooker after 4 hours, shredded it, added the mixture of bbq sauces, and put it in the oven for 30 minutes. I think the problem is I am not a huge fan of things cooked with beef broth. It makes food tastes funny to me. The meat was also fatty, which was not appealing. I could only eat half of the sandwich. I won't be making this again.

text:
The BEST BBQ pork sandwich I have ever had.  After reading the reviews I made the following adjustments; covered the bottom of the crock pot with onion. Then, added 1 can of beer.  Cooked the Pork Roast (3 3/4 lbs.) on low for 8 1/2 hours.  Covered with Cattleman's BBQ sauce and baked @ 350 degrees for 20 minutes.  Baking in the oven is the trick to this recipe.....Again, the BEST BBQ sandwich my family and I have EVER had.  Thanks!

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this on Saturday night.  First, I rubbed a 4 lb pork butt with mccormick grill mates pork rub.  Then, I added the rubbed pork butt, 1/2 diced vidalia onion, 1/2 cup of apple cider vinegar and 1/4 cup of beef broth to a crockpot.  I let this all cook on low for 8.5 hours.  Then, I took out the pork butt and onion and discarded the liquid.  I pulled the meat from the bone and put the pulled pork and onion back in the crockpot with a bottle of Sticky Fingers Memphis BBQ sauce and a teaspoon of liquid smoke and let this all cook on low for 1 hour.  The liquid smoke really made a difference.  Then we made sandwiches with potato rolls.  It was excellent.

text:
Oh YUM! I LOVE slow-cooker meals! I made this last night! I used Reynolds oven bags and lined my crockpot to make clean up a breeze and I followed the recipe except I liberally seasoned the pork shoulder with salt, pepper, and about 2TBSP minced garlic.  I also doused it with about 1/2C Worcestershire sauce. You could probably use pork broth-they sell the pork bullion cubes in the ethnic or Hispanic isle at the grocery store. I chopped half an onion and into 4 quarters and added it to the pot.  I cooked it on high for 1hr and then put it on low to cook overnight. I woke up this morning to a great smelling house and the meat was so tender it fell off the bone.  I drained the liquid, pulled the pork off the bone and added it back to the crockpot with the BBQ sauce turning it to coat. Left it in the crockpot on low until I was finished getting dressed for work and made quite a lunch for my husband and me.  I also made coleslaw the night before to top the sandwiches with and had hamburger pickles and fresh sliced onion on the side and regular Lays potato chips DELICIOUS!!!

text:
This tastes awesome! I'll tell you my secret. This may sound weird, but... I put my pork butt in the crockpot, cover with water and about a cup of strong coffee. YES, I said coffee! I let it cook overnight and then in the morning I remove the pork, shred it, add a bottle of good quality BBQ sauce (don't use a cheap brand) and place on homemade buns (squash rolls from allrecipes is awesome). 

I love this recipe! It's very filling, and for my husband and myself... we don't eat much pork... so this is a treat!

text:
This is a great easy recipe.  I used 2 pork roasts and enough beef broth to just about cover them. Cooked on low for 8 hours. After I shredded the pork I added Jack Daniel's Honey Smokehouse BBQ sauce, a little extra honey, and some of the juices from the crock pot to the casserole dish before placing in the oven. Came out as good as what we get in a restaurant. Serve on a buttered and toasted roll, can't be beat. This will be a well used recipe especially in the summer for picnics and parties!

text:
ABSOLUTELY FANTASTIC!  I put some liquid smoke in with the beef broth while the pork is in the crock pot, shred, mix the bbq sauce with some liquid smoke in the crock pot, put the shredded meat back in and let it heat through.  (Don't overmix the shredded pork or else you'll end up with something resembling wallpaper paste - still good but the texture leaves something to be desired needless to say :) ) This also works well with chicken. I like serving with the Awesome and Easy Creamy Corn Casserole also on this site.  YUM!

userID:
1918292
Display Name:
kristin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
129
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As others have said, I use a 3-4 lb pork roast as it is a cheaper cut of meat that gives you fabulous results.  I put the pork in my slow cooker, toss in some chopped onions, beef broth and a large bottle of bbq sauce (Ken Davis Sweet and Zesty is my favorite) a splash of liquid smoke and cook on low for 10-12 hours.  Remove the pork and shred with 2 forks.  I scoop out as much of the fat that has cooked out of the pork and toss it out.  Yes, you do lose a fair amount of sauce, but after putting the shredded pork back into the crockpot I add a smaller bottle of bbq sauce (I add Ken Davis Bold and Zesty) and heat through.  The pork ends up being a little sweet with a  bbq flavor that appeals to almost everyone.  It so easy to make the night before and then add the 2nd bottle of bbq sauce the next day when reheating.

Loved this! I used a 5lb pork shoulder roast and used 4 cups of beef broth with a bay leaf a few cloves of garlic and half an onion and whole peppercorns and put in the slow cooker for 5 hours on high. The meat literally fell of the bone and shredding it was no problem. My DH rated it a 9 on a scale of 1 to 10. This was so easy. I served it with baked beans, cole slaw, and fries. I will use this recipe for company too!

text:
I have lived in Memphis and Texas, both famous for bbq. This recipe rates amoung the best and the easiest. When I first took the ribs out of the crock pot, they did not seem all that tender, but then I pulled them apart with a fork - and Wow! They were easy to tear apart and just the right amount of tenderness! The first time I made this I used an original Kraft bbq sauce and it was to DIE for! The second time I used another more expensive brand, and it was not near as good. I say KISS (Keep It Simple Stupid!). This is such a quick, easy recipe. Very few steps, cooks on its own, and the taste is out of this world! I made it for my in-laws and VERY picky husband. They loved it! My father-in-law is from the Memphis area and bbqs all the time. He was even impressed and wanted the recipe. Thanks for sharing!!!!!!!

text:
Very good!  And I don't really even like barbeque.  Used Sweet Baby Ray's original BBQ sauce with a dash of the honey kind.  Recommend getting two bottles of whatever you decide to use so you can put some on the buns too.  I didn't put in the oven, but as per some reviews, I drained, shredded and put back in the slow cooker with the barbeque sauce.  I was a little worried about it burning the sauce, but it was fine and heated up fairly fast. Toasted kaiser buns, with sliced pickles...mmmmmmm.

text:
I give this 5 stars but it really does depend on the BBQ sauce you use. Kraft seems to be the worst. I used "Big Bubba's Bad BBQ Sauce" (from a local place) and used about 4 lbs of pork shoulder (and 2 cans of broth because I wasn't sure if it was supposed to be covered) and I got 17 servings for well under $10. It was so delicious that my cat went to great lengths to lick the plate clean, and now won't leave us alone anytime he smells it. And best of all, the man of the house approves tremendously.

I buy small reusable containers that are just the right size for a meal for my husband and myself.  It makes a lot, so I have several perfect meals to pull out in a moments notice. text:
At the suggestion of another reviewer I used pork butt instead.  I slow cooked it for 8 hours and it shredded so easy. I added the bbq sauce and marinated it over night then 4 hours before dinner I put it back in the slow cooker. 

 I will say it was really mushy though. It tastes amazing but the texture is off. I have no problem with texture (I'd never be able to eat sushi if I did) but if that is something that is important to you, I suggest following the recipe and bake it in the oven. I may do that next time around instead of slow cooking it for so long.

text:
Fantastic. I used about 7 lbs of the boneless pork ribs, put on low in the slow cooker for 10 hours and it shredded super easily. Put it in the fridge over night and then addedd Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce, popped it in the oven at 350 degrees for 30 minutes the next morning and transferred it back in the slow cooker on low for ~ 2 hours. BIG hit at a football party, very moist and good flavor. Made a great sandwich with a dash of horseradish.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used pork loin roast because that was all that the store had; 4.8 lbs. Lined the bottom of the crockpot with sliced yellow onion, rubbed the outside of the roast with black pepper and Stubbs BBQ Rub. Placed the roast on the onion and poured two cans of beer around the edges. Cooked on low for 7.5 hours. 

Took it out, shredded it with two forks; it just fell apart. I put in in a large freezer container and added two bottles of Stubb's Spicy BBQ Sauce, covered and put in the fridge for lunch later. 

My husband wouldn't stop picking at it while I was preparing it! He loves it! I will bake up portions as we need them as there are only two of us. Turned out AMAZING!

text:
This was excellent! Best thing about this recipe: VERY EASY AND QUICK! I actually found a couple of 2 lb. boneless pork roasts at Target for $3.50 each since it was close to the Use By date! Threw them in with some beef stock and cooked on low for 5-6 hours, and it fell apart all on its own. Easy to pull into pieces. My seasoning was a personal preference- some pre-made sauce that had a smoked flavor to it, plus a little ketchup, a tiny bit of salt and pepper, and some garlic powder. It was ready instantly, and just fine for us without further cooking or marinating. My girlfriend loved it!

text:
Easiest meal for large groups. I used beer instead of beef broth and pork butt instead of boneless pork ribs (cheaper and more flavorful!!). I put the pork butt and beer in the slow cooker over night on low setting. The next morning, I drained all the liquid from the slow cooker, pulled the pork apart (which if fell apart on its own), and put back in the slow cooker with the bbq sauce on warm for the rest of the afternoon, stirring occasionally throughout the day until the guests arrived. Everyone raved about it!!!

AWESOME!  I use pork shoulder aka pork butt when I make this also.  Before placing the meat in the roaster, I add the broth, chopped onion & minced garlic.  I season the pork with Sweet Mesquite Seasoning (Costco) and Liquid Smoke.  I don't add the BBQ sauce (Sweet Baby Rays original) until after I shred it.  I cook this for about 12-16 hours, drain the excess liquid because the fat cooks off.

This was my first time making barbecue, and I have no reason to ever try any other recipe.  This was delicious...everyone loved it.  I followed the recipe exactly except I did put a chopped onion in the bottom of the slow cooker before I put the pork in. I used Sweet Baby Rays Barbecue Sauce.  Thanks for a recipe that is as easy as it is delicious!

country:

text:
I just made this 2 days ago and I was amazed by how delicious and how easy it really is. I've always wanted to learn how to make pulled pork bbq sandwiches and I am grateful for this recipe. I used a little more than 3lb of country style ribs (they are the ribs cut with most meat). After rinsing and drying the meat, I sprayed my slow cooker and placed the ribs, fitting them tightly. I added on can (it;'s actually 14 oz) of beef stock - next time I'll make my own stock, it's worth it.  After reading the reviews I decied to cook the ribs on low for about 8 hours. In the morning the meat was falling off the bones, I pulled them with two forks and then added less than a bottle of Sweet Ray's BBQ sauce, original recipe. I putted in the refrigerator and ate at night, warming it up on the microwave -- sorry I was hungry and in a hurry! Can't wait for the Spring/summer BBQs so I can do this for a crowd!

text:
Perfect!  I used 3.5 lbs of pork butt which is a much cheaper cut of meat, and it still turned out fantastic.  Put in slow cooker with the beef broth for 5 hours on hi and 3 hours on low.  Then pulled out the meat and shredded it  - but it was so tender it literally shredded itself.  I also separated out all the fat.  Then into the dutch oven with Ray's BBQ sauce for 1 hour.  Served on toasted buns with coleslaw and baked beans.  Oh and don't forget the Eastern Carolina vinegar sauce on top!  This is very simple and easy to follow for a beginner - and the results are almost guaranteed!  Made enough for 2 full dinners for 4 people.

text:
2/10 amy, ruth lunch..the smallest boneless roast in store was 5.5 lbs.  it stuck out the top a little. i cooked on low for 16 hours (only because it was overnight, it wasn't done by the time i went to bed and i read that refrig it and then recook not so good so i left it on low all night.  made this bbq sauce recipe: 1/2 cup cider vinegar 1/2 cup packed brown sugar 1/2 cup ketchup 1/4 cup chili sauce 1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce 2 tbsp chopped onions 1 tbsp lemon juice 1/2 tsp ground mustard 1 clove garlic, minced dash cayenne pepper Combine all sauce ingredients in a saucepan. shred pork, and then put back in crock pot withe the sauce on low for a few more hours (1 would have been fine).  this was't enough sauce i had to add a bottle of jack daniels bbq sauce.  it was very tasty!!lots of leftovers. good with coleslaw.

Hard to rate when you modify someone's recipe. I gave this a four due to not following it to a T.  Something was missing and I can't imagine how it would have taste,  if I didn't alter it. text:
Mmmm...everyone loves this recipe and it is so easy.    I actually smoked pork tenderloin (I like a lean cut) overnight on my gas grill at 200 degrees using hickory chips on the hot side and meat on the cold side and put it in the crock pot, then oven to finish it up the next day.  This is so easy to do on a gas grill...I put it on in the evening and just made sure the temp stayed around 200 and took it off in the morning.  I have made it without smoking it first and it is delicious either way.  However, my mom swears it is so much better when I smoke the meat first.

This was the best pulled pork I have ever made! I used a Boston butt roast, 4.5 lb.My family loved it. I cooked it for 8 hrs. in crook pot with onion slices in bottom of pot, removed to pull the pork, placed in my cast iron skillet, mixed in Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce and cooked in over for 30 min more. text:
This was delicious & easy! I used 3 lbs of boneless loin of pork ribs. I did not have a can of beef broth so I put some water in the bottom of the crockpot under the pork. I cooked it on low for 5 hours, took the pork out, shredded it, added a little salt & pepper & put it back in the crockpot. I poured honey bbq sauce over it & cooked it on low for another hour. PERFECT!

text:
I have used this recipe for the past 3 years to feed 80 - 100 kids from our Church Youth group.  It is easy, I use 2 large crock pots, cook pork shoulders (I buy them in packs of two at Costco) all night, shred them in the morning and add Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce.  Then I put the meat in the refrigerator, then back in the crock pot a few hours before serving to get it warm.  It is a great way to serve a large crowd of hungry teenagers!

None
text:
Great recipe to follow! I used a pork butt, great with one bottle of beer or the can of beef broth.  Cooked on low overnight (7-9 hours), turned off cooker for hour for meat to cool, then trimmed fat and shredded/pulled pork.  Can then be refrigerated with or without bottle of sauce (more or less sauce depending on taste and amount of meat).  Or can be put back on low with sauce for 2 hours or so, maybe longer if coming from refrigerator.  Excellent taste! especially with Sweet Baby Ray's.  Very tender and got rave reviews!

text:
This was AMAZING! I did it a little differently from the instructions. After cooking it in the crock pot, I shredded it in a separate bowl, emptied the broth out of the crock pot, then put the shredded pork back in the crock pot with a smidge of liquid smoke and the BBQ sauce until the rest of the meal was ready. That turned out well, and I didn't have to fire up the oven.

text:
This was soo great and easy! It really doesnt matter how long u put the pork in for your just going to shred it anyways. I used a pork loin roast and put on low for 6hrs. Than took it out saved the broth, threw meat back in with like 1/2 cup of broth and it soaked it right up. Added some spices. Than barbaque sauce and put on warm for a few hours. Didnt have the greatest sauce so I had to throw other ingre. in to livin it up but its not the recipes fault. Put on some buns with some horseradish. Just excellent!! Ive never liked pulled pork but now I do!:)

None
text:
Excellent recipe! Great for those days where you need to do a few things and want to come home to dinner. I made a few changes to the recipe. Another reviewer suggested using a pork butt or shoulder so I did. I added 1 sliced yellow onion to the bottom of the crockpot. I also seasoned the meat with garlic powder, salt and peper rub. Then put in in the crock pot with the beef broth for 4 hours on high. After 4 hours I removed the meet and onions poured out the juice and shreded the meat. Then put the onions and pork into the crock pot w/ 1/2 a bottle of BB-Q sauce on low for 1 hour. Served as suggested -- it was perfect!

text:
So incredibly easy! Tastes like the stuff you buy in the tub at the store, but a wee bit cheaper, with less additives and the satisfaction you get of cooking for yourself. Pork butt or shoulder have both worked very well, both have been inexpensive. I have tried it with the beef broth or a can of beer, both were good but I prefer the beer simmered taste. Then it's mixed with Sweet Baby Rays sauce, hickory & brown sugar. I make sliders using hawaiian sweet rolls, and take them to work for lunch all week. I never get sick of 'em!

This is a super easy recipe.  BBQ sauce is so important.  I used Stub's bbq sauce & found that it lacked flavor.  For some reason it didn't compliment the pork the way I thought it would...Yeah, go figure? Cooking in the oven for 30 minutes makes the edges nice and krisp.  So, next time I will use regular Kraft & will cook in the oven a little longer for more krispness.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Feeding a family of 8, while being able to kick it up a notch to this recipe I use a large, yet inexpensive pork roast.  I dump in a 40 oz bottle of Kraft barbecue sauce. (Sweet Baby Ray's isn't bad either.)  Dump in 1 can of Coca Cola. (If your slow cooker is large enough, add 2 cans of Coke)  Add 1 (8 ounce) can of mandarin oranges with juice.  Add 1/2 cup brown sugar.  Finally I add to that a 28 ounce can of diced tomatoes.  Simmer overnight, remove pork and shred, return to the mixture, and serve over homemade rolls.

My whole family loves this recipe! I threw in a can of beer because I had a pretty darn big roast and I wanted enought liquid. The house still smells good, and I made this last night! Next time I will use more than 18oz bbq sauce, and I am not sure if I will bake it because I prefer juicy meat and the baking dries it out and even burned parts after 30 mins. Still....this is a wonderful dinner!

text:
WOW......This was the BEST BBQ I have had in a long time.  I did follow the recipe and used 3 pounds of country style ribs, with 1 can beef broth.  The ribs were falling apart as I took them out of the crockpot.  Shredding them was no problem, there was hardly any fat at all. The pork was so moist.  I did put it in a dutch oven uncovered for about 35 minutes.  I added extra sauce, we like ours saucy.  Glad I did, because they came out PERFECT.  I made the "Big Al's K.C. Bar-B-Q Sauce" from this site.  I am so glad I did.  Not only have I found my new pork Sandwich recipe, but also a new BBQ Sauce recipe. They compliment each other nicely.  I served on jumbo sandwich buns, with coleslaw and baked beans.  My husband said it was better than going down the street to one of the local BBQ places. I have been craving a Great BBQ sandwich for a couple of weeks now, this definitely hit the spot.  Thanks so much for this FABULOUS Recipe.

text:
I was told by everyone who tried this that it is my best BBQ sandwich yet.  I did modify the recipe a bit.  I used a 3.5 lb pork shoulder instead of ribs.  I put the pork in the slow cooker with a can of beef broth, 1/2 yellow onion and 2 cloves of garlic.  I followed the recipe from there and used my hubby's homemade BBQ sauce on the meat before I baked it in the iron skillet.  After baking it, I put it back in the slow cooker with  1/4 cup red wine vinegar, 1/4 cup balsamic vinegar, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup ketchup, 1/2 cup chili sauce, 1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce, 1 tsp lemon juice, 2 tsp lime juice, 1/2 tsp dijon mustard, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper sauce, 1/4 tsp crushed red pepper flakes, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper and 1/4 tsp Maggi seasoning.  It tasted wonderful!  I have already had requests for it again.

I used pork butt for this recipe.  I put it in the crock pot for 10 hours on low with beef broth & one beer.  After 10 hours I took it out, shredded the meat, added Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ Sauce then spread it into a 9x9 baking pan.  I didn't have a ton of time (everyone was getting hungry)so I just put the meat under the broiler for a few minutes to get the meat a little crispy without having to wait another 30 minutes.  I will definetly make this again!  My husband & brother would not stop talking about how great the sandwiches were that I made.  And what girl doesn't like a little praise?  ;-)

text:
DELICIOUS!!  My crockpot was buried in a cabinet, so I made a few adjustments.  I used about 3 1/2 lbs of boneless ribs.  In a pot, I added the ribs, 3/4 can of low sodium beef broth, 3/4 can of beer, garlic powder, onion powder and black pepper.  I let it cook (covered) low and slow in the oven - about 3 hours at 250 degrees.  I pulled the pork apart with two forks (soooo tender), drained about 1/2 the liquid and added about 2 bottles of BBQ sauce (1 Jack Daniels & 1 Cattleman's - it's what I had on hand).  I stuck it back in the oven at 325 degrees for 30 minutes.  My husband and teenage son couldn't get enough!  Still have a ton left over and hope it freezes well for another meal!

text:
Kind of like the "baby back ribs" recipe, this is more about the cooking process than the actual ingredients - and its important!  I always just poured a bottle of BBQ over some pork and left it in the slow cooker, shredded and plopped it on a roll.  This is sooooo much better.  You get rid of the fat, you get a nice texture from baking, and its just so worth it!!!  BBQ sauce ideas - Sweet Baby Ray's is just too sweet for me, Jack Daniels Hickory Smoke is ok... I prefer Cattlemans so far!

I followed some of the recommendations of other reviewers...I couldn't find boneless pork ribs so I used pork on the bone. Both recipes took very little time and I highly recommend the combination!

text:
WOW! This is fantastic!  After only trying this recipe three weeks ago, my husband has requested it every week. As others suggested I use a pork butt roast, and my butcher removes the bone for me.  I have only made one other change to the recipe, and only because I like a really wet bbq.  Once the pork is ready, I remove it from the slow cooker, pull it apart, and add the bbq sauce. I don't put it in the oven, otherwise no matter how much sauce I add, it seems to make it a little too thick for my liking.  We have it on buttered pan fried sourdough bread, topped with cole slaw and sliced pickles. This recipe is sooo easy and tastes sooo good. If I could, I would rate it a ten!

country:
None
text:
I made this for dinner tonight, it was so easy and so good. I don't have a crockpot so I had to cook it in the oven. So what I did was, I put 2 cups of beef broth in a casserole dish, sprinkled the pork ribs with garlic & onion powder, placed the ribs in the dish, covered it and baked it at 300 degrees for 3 hours. They were so tender, it didn't take hardly anytime to pull them apart, after that I put them in another casserole dish poured my homemade bbq sauce on them gave them a couple of good stirs, covered it and put it in the oven at 325 degrees for 30 min. They were fantastic!!! Thank you so much for sharing your recipe with all of us, will be making this again real soon!!!

text:
I made this yesterday for a bbq.  It was a big hit! Everyone loved it. I used a 5-6 pd. boneless pork butt.  Cooked it for 5 hours on high.  I wanted to make homemade bbq sauce but time was an issue so I used Sticky Fingers Tennesse Whiskey bbq sauce, it was excellent.  I mixed the sauce and shredded pork in a dutch oven and heated it in the oven.  I also made Sweet retaurant slaw (from this site) to go with it. I would definitely make this again. It was nice to have something a little different than just burgers and hot dogs at this point in the bbq season. I ended up with a lot of left over hamburgers!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! Not to mention incredibly simple. Everyone who's tried these have been in love with them. I've made this several times, and I've used the "shoulder butt" cut every time (ask the meat counter to debone the meat for you before you leave the store. It's a breeze for them and free for you). The shoulder butt is a great cut for the crock pot - cheap but still comes out incredibly tender and shreds like a dream. The only downside of the shoulder butt is that it can be quite fatty, but it's not difficult to trim the fat off before throwing in it the crock pot. I serve these on toasted hamburger buns with slice a slice of American cheese and seasoned steak fries on the side. Yum!

text:
Delicious! We followed the recipe but didn't put in the oven. Instead, we put the shredded pork in a pot and added bbq sauce (chris & pitts), garlic salt, 4 oz of Chipotle peppers in adobo sauce (ran through food processor); mixed it all well. Toasted Kaiser roll buns, added the bbq porked, topped with aged swiss cheese and French Fried Onions (sauteed onions might work even better). It was delicious! My picky eater had just shredded pork sandwiches with A1 sauce...he loved them. We accompanied them w/baked beans, fresh veggies (broccoli, carrots & baby spinach) dipped in ranch dressing.

text:
This is "OMG!" good!  I used two 2-lb. pork roasts (they were on sale) and used garlic powder, salt and pepper rub on roasts before adding to beef broth in crock pot.  I cooked on high for 4 hours and the meat was incredibly tender and moist.  After I shredded the meat, I emptied crock pot of broth and added shredded pork and barbeque sauce to heat on low for 5-8 minutes while I prepared the sides.  Finally, I used the "Sweet Restaurant Slaw" recipe on here by Sandi Johnson (made it this morning when I put pork in crock pot) and topped it on the pork and made pork sandwiches.  The slaw was also a 5+ and tasted as good as, or better, than the one that large chicken chain serves.  I highly recommend both!!

text:
Very good and easy to make.  I used a pork roast.  I poured 1/2 of the barbecue sauce into the crockpot with the beef broth and left it to cook for 8 hours.  I then removed the pork from the crockpot and shreded it and placed it in a casserole dish in the oven with the rest of the sauce and a little of the broth from the crockpot for 30 minutes.  I took it to a potluck and it was a hit!

text:
DELICIOUS.
I slow cooked the pork on low for 10 hours, like I read that someone else did, and it was so tender that I couldn't pick it up out of the pot without the help of a spoon!
My husband LOVED it.

After I took out the larger clumps of fat (highly recommend doing) and shredded the pork, I spooned a little of the pot's beef broth juices over the pork to make it real juicy (careful not to make it too juicy though!)

For the BBQ, I mixed some Corky's Smokin Hot BBQ sauce into some KC Masterpiece Original BBQ sauce. The Corky's sauce added a little bite to it-it turned out perfect!

Served on a whole wheat bun with baked beans and cole slaw-what an easy and delicious meal!

My husband and I now want to invite people over for a BBQ with this recipe!
FANTASTIC.

city:

country:

text:
This recipe was fantastic!!  Try it!
I went to Rib-fest not that long ago and had the best pulled-pork sandwiches I had ever eaten.  I tried to replicate and could not. Until now!!  I used a half a pork roast (all I had) and put it in the slow cooker with the broth (all I had was chicken but I tried it anway).  The result was a very moist chunk of meat that shredded in no time.  I added a bottle of Kraft's Brown Sugar BBQ sauce (yes, it's sweet but brown sugar is a main ingredient in great pulled pork sandwiches!).
The quality of your sandiches will largely depend on your choice of BBQ sauce so pick wisely!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
With a solid 5-star rating after 355 reviews, I figured this must be some good BBQ.  Well they were right, add me as number 356.  Fantastic recipe and simple to make!  

I used about 6 lbs of meat - a 3 lb boneless pork loin and a 3 lb boneless pork butt.  I simered the meat with 2 cans of beef broth, diced onions, and diced garlic for just over 4 hours.  I flipped in the pot a couple of times to ensure an even cook.  When done, it was so delicious even before the bbq sauce.  It shredded with ease.  I then mixed it all together with Kraft original BBQ sauce and cooked uncovered in the oven for 30-40 minutes at 350, stirring once.

The only change I would consider is the BBQ sauce.  I think it actually subdued some of the great flavor of the pork.  Other than that, a big thumbs up on this one!!!

I also used Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce, which was fantastic!  I used pork butt shoulder which worked great.  Also added a package of Good Seasons Italian Dressing Mix to crockpot.  I cooked mine overnight since I used 8 lb. and needed it earlier in the day the next day.  My advice is not to overcook or overstir as texture can get pate-like, but still delicious!  To double, I doubled the meat, doubled the sauce, but still only used one can beef broth.

text:
I took this basic recipe and jazzed it up a bit and it turned out amazing! First, slice on medium apple and place 1/2 of it on bottom of cooker, then slice a medium red onion and put 1/2 of the rings on bottom. Place your pork cut on top of apple and onion slices, then pour broth and BBQ sauce over, place remaining onion and apple on top. Slow cook all day and shred ...mmmmmmmmm....sooo good.

This is very easy and delicious.  Obviously you can't beat slow roasting on a smoker, but in the dead of Winter this hits the spot.  I seasoned the meat with some salt, pepper, garlic powder and sage prior to roasting.  I don't have a slow cooker so I roasted the meat covered in the oven at about 325 degrees.  Definitely the barbeque sauce will make or break this.  We like KC Masterpiece Original flavor.  It turned out great.

text:
My family came for dinner last night and this was what I served.  I previously cooked it in the crock pot for about 8 hours (i had a 7 lb pork shoulder roast).  when i took it out, i didn't have much shredding to do because it fell apart when the fork touched it.  i put it in the refrigerator with about a cup of the liquid.  the next day i mixed it with Grant's Famous Midnight Grill BBq Sauce and put it back in the crock pot for 3 hours.  we had fabulous sandwiches and i served it with extra sauce on the side.  awesome and easy recipe.

I used this recipe to make country style ribs for a large group.  I cooked them in aluminum pans covered with aluminum foil in the oven. text:
Made this yesterday in the crockpot. Used a pork loin, a little over 4lbs., two cans of beef broth, and put sliced onion under and on top of loin while cooking.  It took longer to cook than expected,(left pork loin whole)I started on high for two hours then low the rest of the time.  (Should have left it on high with whole loin).  Heard so much in the reviews about Sweet Baby Rays that I bought some and other reviewers were right, wonderful.  I used one whole 18oz. bottle and probably 1/3rd of a second bottle of original after I shredded it.  I also put about 2/3 of a cup reserved broth back in and cooked for about 2 hours on low.  Wonderful, wonderful.  Served with cole slaw, bread and butter pickles and chips.  Thanks for a wonderful recipe.

Very good pulled pork! Prior to putting the boneless pork ribs in the broth, I rubbed Lawry's seasoned salt, garlic powder and pepper into them. I cooked them in crock pot on high for 5 hours, and they pulled apart very easily. I added my favorite Kansas City BBQ sauce that I purchased from a local BBQ restaurant. (most BBQ houses sell their secret sauce if you ask.) I served it to my hungry Hubby along with baked beans, potato salad and an ice cold beer when he got home from a hard day at work.

Oh yum...whenever my family craves bbq, this is the recipe we turn to.  Couldn't be any easier and it's sooooo good!  The only thing we change is rubbing the meat with Corky's bbq rub before placing it in the crock pot. We love it and have received great reviews from friends when they try it.

text:
I used a 3# pork butt roast - cooked on high in the crock pot for 5 hours with the broth and med chopped onion, then shredded.  Put back in the crockpot on low for 1 hr with lots of sauce (you may have to stir occasionally to be sure you have enough sauce on so it doesn't dry out) and served with whole wheat buns, Amish Slaw, and Basked Beans II all from this website.  Ate the slaw on the sandwhich.  Also habanero hot sauce from this site on the side so it was like the Smokey Bones experience for those who liked it hot - Everyone wanted the recipe(*s).

text:
I thought this was really good.  I couldn't find boneless pork ribs, so I grabbed some ribs that were on sale instead and it worked just fine.  I didn't have 3 lbs of meat, but since it had bones, I let it cook for about 3.5 hrs anyway.  It smelled pretty gross while cooking, and the meat was an unappealing grey color (that pork takes on when boiled).  BUT, once shredded and the sauce added, it looked and smelled *so* good.  Your results will depend largely on what sauce you use.  The recipe is easy, and a good way to get bbq sandwiches without a smoker.

userID:
17086508
Display Name:
Allan
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After I read some reviews, I made some changes. I substituted a bottle of beer for the beef broth, because I used a shoulder roast and it had plenty of fat that would negate using more "beef" broth. I also chopped up a whole green bell pepper and about 1/3 of a large onion. I poured the beer in the slow cooker, then the chopped up green pepper and onion then put in a 5.3# pork shoulder. Cooked on high for 4 1/2 hours. Took out the pork and shredded it. It was difficult to do and I was regretting using a cheaper cut, but I did get it all shredded and had about 1/3 of the roast that was fat and gristle which I threw away. Put the shredded pork in a large covered glass casserole bowl, added about a 1/4 cup or so of the remaining liquid. I also strained out the liquid from the pepper and onion pieces and put about half on top of the pork. Then I put in a whole bottle of Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce on top and stirred it all together. Preheated oven 350 and have it about 30 minutes, stirring halfway through the time. The result was the best BBQ we ever tasted! 5 Stars! I am a retired male, my wife is still working so I do the cooking and she loves it!

text:
My husband LOVES pulled pork, and this is the best recipe I have tried so far.  I used a 3-4 pound pork butt (shoulder) and rubbed it with with ground black pepper, onion powder, garlic powder and sage. I chopped 1 medium onion for bottom of crock pot, added the meat and 1 cup water. I let it cook on low 10 hrs.  (5 hours on high) and took it out and let it sit for 10 minutes and discard the cooking liquids. I Shred it up with 2 forks and added BBQ sauce (Sweet Baby Ray's) approx 1 1/2 bottles and baked it as in the recipe.  Loved the crispy ends.  Served on Publix fresh buns.  Served with homemade coleslaw.

When making pulled pork there is only one way to go, bone in Boston Butt, the best cut of meat for pulled pork. Season meat add onions and add two cups of water to a slow cooker. For a 5 lb. cut cook for 5 hours on low or until the meat begins to fall apart. Boston Butt makes a wonderful pulled pork.

My all time favorite recipe for pulled pork. I always rub the meat down (a pork butt or pork ribs) with salt, pepper, garlic powder and minced onion for extra flavor. I place it in the slow cooker with the beef broth and cook as instructed. After shredding with the two forks, I throw it right back in the slow cooker (after draining the liquid out) with a mustard based barbecue sauce. Perfect every time!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night and my husband LOVED it.  I made a few changes though (kind of by mistake).  First I seasoned both sides of the pork (I used a cheaper cut as others have suggested) with a little bit of Worcestershire, salt and pepper before putting it into the crockpot.  I then misread the recipe and added the beef broth and BBQ sauce at the same time and cooked everything on low for 6 1/2 hrs.  After the pork was cooked through, we shredded it and put it in a baking dish and then just took a few spoonfuls of the sauce and drizzled it over the pork (enough to moisten but not have it soaking) & baked at 350.  We didn't bake for too long, probably only 10 mins.  When serving it, we added a little more sauce from the crockpot in the sandwich to make it nice and moist.  Delicious!!

text:
Wow, yummy! I bought a 4lb "pork loin center cut boneless roast" and cut it in two (cause there are only 2 people eating dinner tonight). Then put the pork and broth in the crock pot for about 9 hours (while at work) then took it out, poured the whole 18 oz bottle of BBQ sauce over it and only put it in the oven (in a glass dish cause I don't have a cast iron) for 10 minutes to warm it up. It all depends upon the type of BBQ sauce you buy for flavor. But this was a simple, easy, and yummy way to make dinner!

text:
Another Keeper!  Preteens, teen, and husband all loved this pork!  I did slice an onion for the bottom of the crock- Yummy!  After removing the meat and onions from the crock I strained the juice left and threw long grain rice in the crock with the juice (1/2 the amount of rice as juice) and left the crock on high.  Returned in an hour and the rice was perfect with nice flavors that was an easy side dish.  I'll try egg noodles next time maybe adding a few sliced veggies! The bbq also was good as bbq salad!  I also used Sweet baby Rays for the first time- It was a hit!

text:
I used a 4-1/4 lb pork shoulder blade roast, which the butcher recommended.  Before cooking I removed about 1/2 lb fat, and there was still fat running through the roast (which I was able to remove a lot of while shredding later).  I don't know if this particular roast had more than usual, but I will not use this cut of pork again!  Otherwise, I followed the recipe and it was great - used Sweet Baby Ray's Hickory & Brown Sugar BBQ sauce.  In a taste test, I don't  know if I'd be able to guess which is the Baby Ray's and which is the sauce I used to make, so why not save the time!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent although I have to review the process rather than the recipe as it was written.  Due to dietary concerns, I had to make a low-sugar barbecue sauce.  I also started the recipe late in the day and didn't have the time to make this is a crockpot.  I put a pork butt roast in a heavy pan along with beef broth and let it cook on the stove for 3-4 hours until the meat was tender.  I added my barbecue sauce after shredding the pork and did let it cook a little longer.  I think it will be even better after it sits.  Next time, I will make the meat a day ahead to allow for this.  I made the restaurant style cole slaw from AR as an excellent accompaniment.  My husband loves pulled pork and this was my first time trying such a recipe--it's definitely a keeper.  Thanks for a wonderful, easy recipe!

text:
First time I made pulled pork.  Except for putting in an onion, I followed recipe as written....Cooked the pork in the slow cooker the day before.  The next day, I placed the pulled pork in the cooker, put in some of the natural juices/with half a bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's on "Hi" for two hours.  I stirred a couple of times (the meat even browned).  Served with extra sauce (and cole slaw) on the side.  WONDERFUL!!!!!

text:
I used pork butt instead of the ribs because the store was out of them, but it still turned out great. I cut up an onion and put the pork on top of that, then poured in about a cup of beef broth and 1/2 of a bottle of beer and cooked it on low for about 8 hours. I drained the juices and put the pork back in the crock pot with a bottle of BBQ sauce and let it cook for another hr or so. By that time I barely needed to shred the pork and it was perfect.

text:
This recipe is so easy and so delicious!  I'm not that creative in the kitchen, and I was a little intimidated about separating the meat from the fat and the bone (I followed an earlier suggestion of buying meat on the bone because it's cheaper), but it was so easy!  I put it in the crockpot for two hours on high and 6 hours on low, and the meat just fell off the bone.  The "pulling" part took way less time than I expected.  I love BBQ sandwiches, and I couldn't wait to taste a little before my husband got home.  It's out of this world!  I'm serving it tonight with Hidden Valley Ranch potatoes and green beans. I will definitely make this again for just the two of us, and I can't wait to make it for a crowd.

text:
So easy, and an endless variety of options to tweak it. I followed the recipe, except I did buy a cheaper cut. Got a 4 lb. shoulder roast, bone in. Shredded beautifully after 4 hours in the crock pot. Did the oven thing as stated-nicely done. Next time I'll try beer and then cola. Also I will vary the BBQ sauce-the one I used had a guy's pic on it and it said, "My life is in these bottles," but I forget what it was called. I'd say the flavor was okay, though my picky husband and 12 yr old daughter raved about it. I think there are ways to make it more flavorful, but I wouldn't want it to be spicy. So I'll play around. Our family of 5 ate all 4 lbs. in 2 days.

text:
I definitely changed this one up a bit, but it gets 5 stars none-the-less because it was so amazing. I agree, a cheap cut of pork works great for this.  I uses about a quart of beef stock as I wanted some to freeze for later cooking. I cooked it for about 7 hours, then added about 1/2 tablespoon of crushed garlic and 1/8 tsp liquid smoke. I let it simmer for another 1/2 hour. I served pulled pork sandwiches with bbq sauce on the side right away then saved the rest for enchiladas the next day. This is a great versatile recipe!

I love having dinner ready when I get home and this is one of those recipes that is easy for a busy mom to throw in the crock pot in the morning and feed a hungry family the instant you come home.  I can't live without these types of recipes.  I did use a pork shoulder instead of the more expensive meat.  Fell apart easily.

userID:
2918010
Display Name:
BJS

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was certainly very easy!  Although somewhat bland, the meat was tender. As others suggested, I used a pork butt instead of ribs and cooked it on low for about 10 hours. It rendered a LOT of fat. I refrigerated it overnight and easily removed the fat after it hardened.  Instead of bottled, I used a homemade ketchup/vinegar/brown sugar/ground mustard, etc. BBQ sauce recommended by a previous reviewer.  Maybe the bottled would have been better.  I wound up having to do a lot of adding/adjusting of ingredients to get the taste right.  I had to thicken the sauce a bit with about 1/4 c. of instant potatoes.  This was also probably the result of my using the butt roast instead of ribs.  All in all, this is a good starter recipe that can be adapted to individual tastes.

text:
This was awesome and very easy to make.  I followed the suggestions of some of the other members and cooked a pork shoulder in the crock pot with the beef broth.  Then mixed it with some of the left over cooking liquid and the (sweet and tangy BBQ sauce) recipe from this site the next day and warmed it up in the crock pot on high for about 2 hours.  Again this was very very good and easy to do, this will be a regular addition to my summer menu.

text:
This was awesome! I had a large Boston butt that I had to cut in half to fit in my slow cooker. I ended up slow cooking half and cooking the other half in the oven (200 for 3 hours) and couldn't tell the difference between the two. I did include one cut up onion and a can of beer with the half of butt I slow cooked. I then mixed both together and with Sweet Baby Ray's and cooked in the oven. I really think this last step is necessary. It makes it seem more like pork that's been grilled or smoked and then barbecued.

Super easy recipe.  I followed others suggestion and used pork shoulder instead of the more expensive cut called for in the recipe.  I threw in an onion and cooked on 4 hr HI, 2 hr LO, the refrigerated for 2 hrs and finished off in a dutch oven per the recipe.  My whole family loved it - my daughter said it was "Awesome".  I usually like my pork w/ more texture, so next time i'll stick to the 4 hrs.  This recipe will be a keeper!

country:
None
text:
this was so good. I added a diced onion and a diced green pepper to the slow cooker, cooked on low for 6 hours, drained, shredded the pork, added the bbq sauce (i used famous daves rich and sassy), let it sit in the fridge for two hours, then put it in the oven. i noticed that a lot of reviewers said they just put it back in the slow cooker after adding the bbq sauce. i'm sure that's still good, but i thought the oven really did wonders for the texture (i've noticed that slow cooker pulled pork is mushy sometimes, and this was anything but).

text:
Tried this recipe the other night in the crockpot and it came out very tasty (with alterations)! My guyfriend even said this sandwich tasted better than what he might find at a restaurant. Nice compliment. :) Super-easy to make too!  I used pork butt (1.6 lbs.) and trimmed the fat before placing it in the crockpot along with approx. 1/2 can of beef broth, a few ounces of beer (1554 black ale), a smidgen of french onion soup dry mix, and a few sprinkles of garlic powder. For BBQ sauce, I used Famous Dave's Sweet & Zesty.   Made the perfect amount for 4-5 hoagie buns. I did finish cooking it in the oven and felt this improved the texture.   Thanks for the recipe! I never even realized I liked pulled pork sandwiches, but this convinced me. :)

text:
This is fantastic! I listened to the previous suggestions and used a cheaper cut (only $1.59/#)! I used 2.5 lbs of meat and 16 oz. of broth, and cooked in crock-pot for 6 hrs on low. Then I shredded the meat (very tender and easy), and to keep the heat out of my kitchen in the summer, I mixed in the 1/2 jar of BBQ sauce and returned to the slow cooker for another 45 min. Turned out great, and everyone raved about it!

I followed this recipe exactly (aside from using a trimmed butt roast) and it is absolutely perfect as is. DO NOT SKIP THE OVEN STEP! It is worth the extra dirty dish. I want to try this with chicken and beef also, just for a different taste, but I'm sure it will be equally tasty and wonderful!

i season the pork w/ some salt, pepper, onion power, garlic powder, cayenne pepper, and paprika before i stick it in the crock pot w/ the broth. i've cooked this for 4 hrs and 10 hrs before and prefer the 4 hr version because it has more texture where the 10 hr is more mushy. lastly, i top the burger w/ coleslaw before i devour.

country:
None
text:
This was great ! I had 3 1/2 lbs of boneless rib, cut them into 1/2's, added the broth, 2 tbps of hickory smoke flavored marinade, a cup of water &  1 beef bullion cube. Slow cooked in crockpot for 4 hrs. After shredding, I drained & put pork into a cast iron pot on stove top, added a bottle of vinegar based BBQ sauce & a few dashes of cayenne pepper. (E. Carolina style BBQ)Simmered for 1 hr, stirring about each 15 minutes. Great recipe. We served with cole slaw on buns with chips. Just my wife & I, froze the remainder in qt size freezer bags.

My advice is to not substitute a thing, this is the best recipe as is!

text:
Do not substitute a lower cut of meat like some have suggested.  This recipe is perfect with the boneless rib meat.  I tried the shoulder as some said would turn out as good. HOGWASH!! People advocating a lesser cut may have weaker taste buds.  Even my kids could tell the difference.  I used the same exact recipe as always with one change, the shoulder cut.  Which by the way yielded much less meat and more fat with bones.  So it could have cost about the same or even more per pound.  Also, unless you like the smell of pork bones simmering in your house please don't do this!

My favorite way to prepare this is with a picnic/butt cut of pork. After I shred the meat, I toss the meat back in the slow cooker (liquid poured out), add Stubb’s barbecue sauce (1/2 mesquite, 1/2 spicy), and cook on low until heated through. Display Name:
Sharon

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Cooked this for Sunday dinner, it turned out well. I did not exactly follow the recipe as specified. I used a 5lb boneless pork shoulder instead of the ribs. Created a spice rub of garlic powder, onion powder, dried mustard, brown sugar, cayenne pepper, black pepper and kosher salt (about 2T each). Coated all sides of the meat and browned in a cast iron skillet before adding to the crockpot.  Added 2 chopped onions and 4 cloves of garlic to the bottom of the pot before adding the meat. I thought 4 cups of beef stock was to much, used only 3 cups with a couple of dashes of worcestershire sauce and liquid smoke. Cooked for 6 hours on low. Meat easily pulled apart with forks but I that it was too wet. Added 2 bottles of Jack Daniels Hickory Brown Sugar BBQ Sauce along with some a couple dashes of hot peper sauce, cayenne pepper and 1/2 cup of cooking liquid . Baked cover in a ceramic dish for 30 mins, removed lid and stirred meat to get more crispy piece. Put back in the stove for 20 mins uncovered. Family really liked it. Made plenty for leftovers, even froze a container full for a future date. Well use again with my additions.

text:
This is a tried and true never fails crowd pleaser.  Great for the big game.  If your rooting for the Steelers this weekend then you have to put a Pennsylvania twist on this recipe.  Use Yuengling Lager BBQ sauce and a bottle of Yuengling Lager.  I know Wegman's has the sauce but buy the beer at your local distributor.  Serve it on a pretzel roll with slaw.  I also recommend using a slow cooker liner to make cleanup a little easier.

i made this recipe only because it was so easy and only needed 3 ingredients. i thought it can't be that bad, to my surprise it was incredible!!  i love BBQ sandwiches but don't like to pay $3-4 dollars for one sandwich at food places.  with only $2 worth of pork (it was on sale) we made 5 sandwiches. the only thing i did different was after pulling the pork from the crock pot i added it to a sauce pan with a little hot sauce and BBQ sauce and heated it up on the top burners, (i was in a rush, and i had some hungry people waiting). my only regret was that i didn't make more.  can't wait to make it again for company that is coming from out of town, gonna make tons!!

text:
Definitely need to bake for the last 30 min -- makes it awesome!  I cooked a 3 lb. shoulder with a can of beef broth, maybe 8 oz of beer, some minced dried onion, and onion salt for 10 hrs. then pulled the pork and stored in the fridge until the next day when I topped with bbq (Sweet Baby Ray's), and baked for 30 min.  So good on buns with provolone cheese and a slice of pineapple!

text:
Great basic recipe.  Because we had some friends who keep Kosher joining us for dinner, I used a bottom round roast instead of the boneless pork ribs.  I created a dry rub for the meat using garlic salt, dried parsley, dried oregano, dried thyme, and black pepper.  I coated the outside of the meat with the dry rub and let it sit overnight.  In the morning, I seared the meat on all sides and then put it in the slow cooker and followed this recipe.  It was delicious!  Can't wait to hit those leftovers!

text:
This recipe was delicious!  The only thing I did differently was cook it for 10 hours on low (while I was at work).  I've cooked it twice (in one week) and used a different type of bbq sauce each time.  The first time I used Kraft Hickory BBQ sauce - I really liked that because it was not as sweet.  The second time I used Sweet Baby Rays - this was also very good but gave the BBQ a much sweeter taste.  I served it on toasted hamburger buns with homemade sweet and spicy coleslaw and corn on the cob for sides.  Yummy!  Oh, I also agree that you should not skip putting it in the oven.  I stirred it every 10 minutes.

text:
This is a great basic recipe.  Just throw in the beef broth and forget it.  I didn't have a chance to put it in the oven, which I'm sure would have been even better with the carmelization.  However, the meat was so tender, that I just added the BBQ sauce (Sweet Baby Ray's) and it was great.  At first, I thought there was too much liquid, but I served it over rice and it was awesome.  Next time I will try it with the oven part too.  I used a pork butt for this recipe, but you could probably use anything.... beef, chicken, any cut of pork.  If you are a busy mom (or dad) this is a great timesaver and it makes the house smell great.

I made this for my family one night for dinner.  My sis is really picky and she loved it (very surprised).  I modified this recipe a lil due to what we had in the house.  I used a 5 pound pork roast and cooked it with 1 can of beef broth and 1 can of water.  I cooked it for 5-6 hours in the crock pot.  Then we added a full bottle of sweet baby rays regular and half bottle of sweet baby rays hot and spicy.  This gave it some flavor.  It was so delicious and gone within a few days!

I followed the general advice with this and it came out fantastic, made a bunch of it for father's day for my dad. Put about 4 pounds of butt roast in slow cooker at midnight (lots of fat to trim off though) with the broth. Forked it at 10 am with it falling all apart. I do recommend doing the last 30 minutes in the oven, it makes the top nice and crispy and awesome. I used Sweet Baby Ray's for the first time and it is, duh, sweet, so had I realized that I would have went for something more mesquite.

text:
Well, I used beef ribs and this was really fabulous. 3# beef country ribs, 1 12 oz. can of beer in my pampered chef covered baker, 350 degrees for 2.5-3 hours.  Broke apart easily with a fork and I let it cool to skim the fat.  Next day I made the sauce by amethystshells, I 1.5 timed the recipe, cooked in on the stovetop for a half hour added to the shredded beef, which still had some of the juice and put in a 350 degree oven with no lid for 45 min.  I will make this again, Thanks!

text:
This is a very easy recipe & tastes great!  We used pork butt & cooked in the slow cooker for 10 hours (with 2 cans of beef broth - I'm always afraid of things being dry), shredded it immediately, added 1 bottle of barbecue sauce and stuck it in the oven at 170 degrees so my very active family could eat in shifts. We all loved it & this will be the only way I make BBQ pork from now on.  Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
I loved this recipe, even though I had a little trouble shredding the pork.  I used the recipe "vinegar based BBQ Sauce" on this site and it was amazing.  I added some extra bottled barbecue sauce and it added another level of richness.  This pork was great and I got amazing reviews from all who tried it. 
EDIT
I tried this recipe again and used 3 bone-in pork but steaks and cooked them on LOW for 8 hours, they literally fell off the bone and I had to scoop them out they were so tender, used a mix of vinegar based BBQ sauce and KC Masterpiece Original bottled BBQ sauce and it turned out great.  Thanks for this recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I listened to previous users and tried two different roasts.  The first time I used a tenderloin roast (because that was in the freezer) and the next I used the shoulder roast.  I slow cooked in beer for both and they fell easily apart.  The only thing is the shoulder is very fatty so you have to pick more out.  I then drained half the liquid out and put it in a roaster in the oven with the bbq sauce uncovered at 350 for 30 min.  This really baked in the flavor.   Both were great, but I would have to say the shoulder was more flavorful. My family wolfed this down with large hamburg rolls,(canned) baked beans and a salad.

text:
I doubled this recipe and put about three pounds in each slow cooker. I used someone else's suggestion, and put a bottle of beer in each crock pot. One I did a Black Butte Porter and the other Bud Light. I used two different types of barbecue sauce too, one was Sweet Baby Ray's and the other was a Honey BBQ from Kraft. Both turned out great, but I was concerned they were a bit overcooked. Make sure not to overcook the pork!

text:
I just got done making this recipe.
I used a pork roast in my not so good slow cooker for a little less than 8 hours. I tasted the meat to see the texture and it was SO tender. After reading some of the reviews, I decided to take the meat out and just return it back to the slow cooker after I drained the broth.
I added in some of the BBQ sauce we got... I don't particularly like the sauce we did get though.. would've prefered the Carolina mustard based style with this sandwich or something a bit sweeter. 
We got one that's pretty spicy (fiance's choice).
But other than the mistep with the sauce, the meat is just absolutely deliscious!!

text:
I didn't use the same ingredients, but this was delicious!  I started with a trimmed 4lb pork sirloin roast, 14 oz of chicken broth, and about 1/2 cup BBQ sauce.  After cooking I drained the meat in a colander over a large bowl to catch the broth, then added 1 c BBQ sauce and 1/3 c broth to the shredded meat to moisten it and it was perfect.

text:
Very simple.  I made bourbon whiskey bbq sauce (from this site) two days before just for this recipe.  I ended up buying a boneless pork shoulder and cooked that in the beef broth and a tablespoon of liquid smoke.  It was a little tough to tear apart at first, but then I threw it all back into the crockpot with two cups of my pre-made bbq sauce for about an hour until it was heated through.  It was very tender and delicious.

text:
Deeeeee-licious!  I wanted something warm to come home to after an outdoor Christmas Eve service at church.  This was perfect.  I used a 4 lb. pork roast and cooked it in the crockpot for about 8 hours on Low with 16 oz. water mixed with dry onion soup mix and a diced onion.  When we got home from church, I shredded the meat and stirred in some Jack Daniels BBQ sauce and a splash (or two) of Louisiana Hot Sauce.  I didn't even have a chance to stick it in the oven.  My husband and 4 teenage boys gobbled it up.  I pulled out some store-bought mustard potato salad and coleslaw and I had a houseful of happy eaters.  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
Delicious!  I used a 4.5 lb pork loin roast and cooked it in the slow cooker for just about 10 hours on low.  It fell apart with hardly any assistance from me it was so tender!

I put about 1 cup of the broth into the broasting pan with the meat and approximately 20 oz of Sweet Baby Ray's bbq sauce.  Then, just like the recipe called for, I baked it for 30 minutes.  

It was phenomenal!  I will definitely be making this one again.

This was excellent and SUPER easy! I basically followed the recipe, however, I took a few other reviewer's suggestions and browned the meat first (I used 2 Pork Picnic Roasts) and added an onion and some garlic to the slow cooker. Thanks for the recipe!

Made this for a party this past weekend - everyone loved it.  I was doing a triple batch, so I made the meat in advance and froze it until the day of the party.  Thawed it and put it in the crock pot w/some new beef broth  for moisture and added Sweet Baby Ray's sauce to taste.  Left the bottle out for guests to add more as needed. My husband and I will make this again for ourselves.

text:
I was worried at first.  When I think of bbq, naturally a grill or smoker comes to mind.  I used 5 pounds of country style ribs, since I wanted the flavor from the bones.  I rubbed a little liquid smoke on them, then placed them in the crock pot along with the broth.  I let them cook on low for 5 hours, then shredded the meat and added about a half cup of Sweet Baby Ray's sauce.  I don't like my pork swimming, just a little moist taste works well for us.  The sandwiches came out delish!!  My girls who call everything "chicken" couldn't get enough!  Also, the meat flavored up some baked beans really well!  Great meal for a busy day or even company!

text:
This was the best and so simple to make.  I placed the ribs in a crock pot with beef STOCK, onion, garlic and diced carrots and cooked them on low all night.  In the morning the meat almost fell apart.  I added 3 to 4 ladles of the stock, Jack Daniels Original BBQ sauce as well as Sweet Baby Ray's Original and his new Hickory & Brown Sugar BBQ sauces. Refrigerated all day to blend flavors and reheated for about 45 min. before serving.  Served on Kaiser rolls with a side of cole slaw and dill pickles.  This is a keeper.....  YUM!

text:
Excellent!  This was super easy to make and tasted fabulous as my boyfriend said over and over again.  I myself thought it was really good too, but it was a little to sweet for me.  I used Sweet Baby Ray's original, so I think next time I will try using another bbq sauce that is less sweet.  I took others advice and added chopped onion, green pepper and a little minced garlic to the broth before adding the pork loin roast.  I cooked everything on high for 5 hours and removed the meat and the veggies and  drained the liquid off before shredding.  I added the meat and cooked onion/green peppers back to the crock pot and mixed in the bbq sauce and cooked this on low for another hour before serving on wheat buns. I was told that this is a definite keeper, so I'll be making this again.

I was looking for something for dinner that didn't require the guys leaving the TV on race day, this recipe fit the bill. As an added bonus, it tasted great. I used fresh ham roast and a bottle of Budweiser(keeping with race day tradition) instead of the beef broth. The roast required a little more cooking time, 6 hours on high in the slow cooker instead of four, but the meat pulled apart effortlessly. I put the shredded pork back in the slow cooker and added thinly sliced onion, green pepper and red pepper along with the bbq sauce. I cooked it on low about an hour.

country:
