text:
I made this for our Super Bowl party and everyone loved it!  I just used a pork roast.  It took a little time to pull it apart, but it was easy.
I made it with Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce and it was a hit!
I cooked the roast for about 6 hours, took it out and pulled it apart and then put it back in the crock pot with the BBQ sauce for about 1-2 more hours.  The pork sucked up the BBQ sauce so I'm glad I had two bottles on hand.
I only did one other thing different.  Since I had a three pound roast, the beef broth didn't cover even half of the roast.  I was afraid the roast would burn so I wanted it to be completely submurged in liquid.  I didn't have any more beef broth so I filled my crockpot with water.  I added some garlic and onion slices to make sure it still had taste.  It still came out great!

text:
Used 4 pound pork butt with bbq rub in a ziplock bag overnight. Cooked in crockpot with 1/3 cup water about 10 hours in low. Removed excess broth and sprinkled red chipotle powder, sprinkle brown sugar, a few good of shakes of apple cider vinegar and 1/4 bottle hickory and brown sugar bbq sauce. My husband ate it by itself! It goes great with spicy dill pickles. I’ll try a dash of liquid smoke next time. It’s a keeper!

text:
Cooked approx 5 lbs of pork butt (after trimming quite a bit of fat) in beef broth on high for 4.5 hours and had my guests pour on desired BBQ sauce. Worked great for me! If you're looking for the most basic recipe to do shredded pork--this is it. 
I will say that it took me a long time to trim the fat off before putting it in the crock pot, but I'm sure others would have a better technique. So make sure you reserve time for trimming just in case!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4816664.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed recipe exactly! Came out awesome- except I will say cooking on high for 4hrs is nice when you are in a time crunch, but slow and low reveals more tender pork! I’ve made other recipes with the same cut of pork that felt a bit more tender. I like low 6-8 hrs vs the 4 on high. Adding the beef broth is genius. I used the oven and it really does make a HUGE difference! Stop putting your meat back in the crock pot! This will be my go-to recipe with the exception of cooking low vs high. I used Bull’s-Eye Original bbq sauce because my husband isn’t crazy about sweeter sauces, and served with salt and vinegar chips for lunch and it was so tasty!! We both had multiple helpings! I also saved the broth juice for our fur babies- we don’t feed them table scraps, but anytime I have broth left over, I mix it in with their dry dog food and they go bananas for it! Both are passed out happily sleeping with full bellies! We might be next!

text:
This is what I would call "Cheat BBQ" I made this as written. 
It is EASY, and SIMPLE! That is what I need sometimes.
I feel like the choice of broth and bbq sauce can make or break the recipe. Toasted hamburger buns pushes it over the top.
After making this for years.. the combo I love the most is homemade beef broth and Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce. 

 I took off a star because the information on type of sauce and broth is missing...use the wrong kind and you'll have a bland meal not worth the cost of the pork.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have two active kids who play sports, so I am always looking for a good slow cooker recipe that has dinner mostly completed by the time we get home to eat. I am at a loss as to how this recipe is so highly rated. As written, this lacks any flavor and I had to doctor the final result so much, it isn't even close to being what is written. Flavorless would be the best way to describe the Pork before you add the  barbecue sauce, and honestly, if the sauce is what gives it all the flavor, why not cut to the chase and just add a bottle of sauce and skip the slow cooker all together. And being from the South, adding a bottle of BBQ sauce is not what I consider a good barbecue recipe.  I added onion powder, garlic salt, a bottle of Not Your Father's root beer, and some hot sauce, and it was edible, but both kids and the husband said to throw the recipe away. I have to agree with another reviewer--the people who rated this highly doctored it well past the original recipe, and that is not a true reflection of what you will get if you follow the directions. Meat is expensive--save your money and try another recipe.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-07-12T23:29:17.587

Display Name:
Jayme Cox Bruce

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2303950.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Based on what I had in the house, and what was most cost effective, I did this: Used a 3.5 lb pork butt roast, and swapped the beef broth for Coca-Cola, and doubled it. I also had an onion that needed to get used, and I thought that would add some nice flavoring, so I sliced it up and threw it in with the meat. Based on our schedules, I let it go on high for 10 hrs. The meat was very tender and fell apart easily. The onions were soft, and sweet and tasted great with the meat. I drained the cola out, then put the meat and onions back in the slow cooker, and poured a full bottle of Sweet Baby Rays over everything, and then left the slow cooker on "keep warm" for about an hour and a half until we were ready to eat dinner. Served with toasted sesame seed buns, cole slaw, and chips.

text:
I followed a few suggestions from previous reviews. I bought a Boston Butt, seasoned with rub a butt season and a little hickory. I cooked on high for 4 hours, cut, shredded and continued cooking in juice from beef broth on low over night. I drained the juices off meat and poured on a delicious mustard based sauce and continued to let simmer in crock pot. The meat melted in our mouth. Was AMAZING.  This will be a regular at my house. Made with my famous  potato salad, bison burgers and bratwurst.

text:
yummy yummy, I seared the meat after agressively seasoning with salt and pepper.  Put the meat on top of some diced onions, poured a beer over and slathered on a bit of grainy mustard.  4 hours later on high, shredded everything and put in the fridge until dinner.  Then mixed in the Kathy's Award Winning Barbeque sauce from this site and baked in the oven for a bit to get the crusty edges.  Totally awesome and the meat was not mushy as it can sometimes get in the slow cooker.

text:
Love this recipe, I have tried it twice now and followed what it said the first time. The second time I was in the mood to experiment and used beer like one of the past reviews. It turned out awesome and had a great flavor! I would recommend making sure that you cook the roast long enough though, so that it shreds easily. This last time I cooked it for 4 hours and it didn't shred so easily (25 min. to do it). Other than that just make sure you use a good hoppy beer and you are in business.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Edit: I made this for an Easter party and got great reviews from everyone! The night before I boiled the pork on the stove for about 3 hours on med-high heat and shredded it that night. I also used some of the broth to keep the pork moist overnight in the fridge. The next morning, I put the pork and the bbq sauce in the crock pot and left it on high til it got warm and switched it to low when the guests arrived. It's such an easy dish that can feed lots of people and I love it because it stays warm in the crock pot. I love this recipe! 


So easy!! It really is effortless! I used pork butt and only had it on high for about 2 hours and it came out juicy and tender. After shredding it, I rinsed out the pot and put it all back in with the bbq sauce. This would be great for parties since its so easy..

text:
Wow, amazing pulled pork!  Delicious!  My boys LOVED it!  This is the best reciped ever!  The pork is sooo flavorful.  Definately don't skip the oven part (it REALLY infuses the flavor)!!!!!  I used "boneless pork country ribs" that I got at Winco on sale.  I suppose you could use any cut of meat (pork) but why would I when these turned out soooooooooooooooooo yummy!  I think I will stick with this cut of meat!  This is one of my new top recipes.  A frequent flyer at our house (especially on lazy Sunday afternoons after it cooks aaaaalllllll day).   Get good quality buns (not hamburger buns)..... this pork is worthy of it!  I used sweet baby Rays bbq sauce.    YUM!  YUM!   YUM!!!

text:
I tried this recipe today for our church group and it was a BIG hit! I used a 6.5 lb. pork shoulder and seasoned it with salt,pepper & garlic powder. I cooked it in beef broth with a few minced cloves of garlic for 10 hours on low. The meat shredded SO easily. I added Sweet Baby Ray's Honey BBQ sauce and let it heat for another hour before I served. I served it on rolls with macaroni salad and sweet potatoes. SO DELISH.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So good, and so easy!  I followed the recipe fairly closely.  My only change was to use a Boston Butt instead of the ribs.  I cooked it on high high in my crockpot for 4 hours, then transferred it to my dutch oven where I shredded it, removed any excess fat, and mixed in my fave bbq sauce (Sweet Baby Ray's).  After that I put it in the fridge til the next day, when I warmed it in the oven at 350 for 1/2 hour.  I served it on rolls with cole slaw, and it was a huge hit.

text:
I used a shoulder as well, and wasn't sure about the cooking time to use.  I work for 7 hours, and couldn't turn it off after 4, so I cooked it on low setting.  When I cut into it, it wasn't quite ready, so I turned it up to high for another hour and 45 minutes, and it was perfect.  It shredded easily.  Next time I'll try a medium setting for the whole day. I followed the rest of the recipe, and cooked it in the oven 350, for 30 minutes.  Used Sweet Baby Ray's sauce, and I have to say this turned out perfectly.  thanks for a great recipe!

text:
This was very tender and juicy! I found it a tad too salty for my taste (even without adding any salt), possibly due to the beef broth, so I may try only using half of the broth then adding in water. Once the pork was done (about 5.5 hours in the slowcooker on high for a 4 lb. pork shoulder butt), I toasted ciabatta rolls, then piled on the pork. Served with baked potato chips and a pickle slice... Yummy!

text:
The sauce is the key in this dish.  I tried used Kraft Hickory and it was gross.  Next time I'll make sure I pick something of more quality.  I did mine on low for 9 hours, then in the oven for 15 on 350.  The roast came out wonderfully, and you could even skip the oven step.  I didn't add the BBQ until then, so I wanted the flavors to meld some more.  Super easy. Thanks!

text:
I slow-cooked a 2Lb pork sirloin roast for 3 hours on med-high, shredded, then cooked another 45min in the bbq sauce on low since the meat was already finished. For the sauce I used a bottle of cheap hickory honey bbq sauce, then added 1.5Tbs of Stubb's Inferno Chicken Wing Sauce (whoa! Added a nice kick!) and 2tsp white sugar. The meat was  deliciously tender, making for great sandwiches.  This is the 1st time I've cooked with this cut of meat, and I'll be using it for slow cooking roasts more often.

text:
Fantastic!!!  Only modifications was using 1 12 oz. bottle of Firestone Double Barrel Ale in addition to the 14oz. of Beef Broth.  Used Sweet Baby Ray's as well.  I would keep extra on hand for those that like to sauce it up more.  I didn't have to switch to a pan as well.  Just drained the ceramic pot from the slow cooker, hand shredded the meat and put it back in the ceramic pot...mixed the sauce in and popped the inner pot into the oven for the 30 minutes.  Fantastic!!!  A definite keeper.  You cannot go wrong with this recipe at all.

Probably would make again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Living in eastern North Carolina, I wouldn't even think of using a barbecue sauce on my pork, so I tried this recipe a bit differently. I use a 16 oz bottle of apple cider vinegar instead of the beef broth, and let the pork sit in that over night in the refrigerator. The next morning I set the crock pot on low for about 10 hours. It didn't have enough bite to it, so I mixed about two tablespoons of red pepper with a half cup more of vinegar, and mixed that in with the shredded pork before putting it in the oven. It turned out really well.   I'll definitely be making this again and again. It's simple to make, and makes 8 sandwiches for a grand total of about $11 (including the buns).

text:
This was great. I modified it a bit. I used an 8lb pork shoulder and cooked it in a crock pot with beef stock with chili powder and brown sugar on it's high setting for 10 hours. Then shredded it with forks, it fell off the bone and fat, and baked it in the oven for 30 min with sweet baby rays BBQ sauce mixed with brown sugar chili powder and hot sauce. Served it at a football party and everyone loved it.

To Jill from New Jersey....if it was hard to shredd, then you didn't cook it long enough. When pork is cooked the proper length of time, it is always 'very' tender. I have been cooking for over 40 yrs., and the 'best' cut of pork for BBQ is always a Boston Butt. I have always cooked mine in my pressure cooker because it is so much quicker, but this recipe sounds good.

I got a 4.5 lb pork butt. Although next time I will go with a meat that is less fatty and will probably be easier to shred.  I cooked it with 12 oz of beer instead of beef broth in my slow cooker on high for 4 hours (internal temp was 160 degrees) and then coated it in cattlemans bbq sauce and put it in the oven for 30 minutes at 350 degrees.  Came out sooo moist. My fiance loved it. Definitely made enough for at least 6 sandwiches.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this more than 2 times now, and it came out perfect everytime I make it. Boyfriend and his dad thought I was a superb cook! As per other reviewers' suggestion, I used a cheaper cut of pork like a butt roast.  I have also used pork tenderloin too. They both turn out good.  I put the roast in the slow cooker at about noon, let it cooked until about 4 p.m., drain, pulled it apart and put lots of bbq sauce over it and continue cooking it in the slow cooker. Served with a can of baked beans, a bag of slaw and bottled slaw dressing, and chips. DELICIOUS and EFFORTLESS!

text:
I have cooked this meal 2 times now.  The first time I followed the recipe and it turned out great, except there was a few corners of the meat that got dried out as the broth evaporated.  The second time I cooked it in one of those oven/crock pot bags on med temp.  It cooked twice as fast that way and was super moist.  After I shred the meat I divide it in two seperate pans for the oven that way I can make a spicy bbq mix for my husband and a mild one for the kids and everyone gets what they want.

text:
i was on a "memphis in may world championship" bbq team.  i never thought you could make bbq anyway other than on a smoker/grill.  well, i made this and it was the best pulled pork i've ever had.  i used a pork butt, and the only alteration i would make is to add about a tbsp of liquid smoke, to give it a smokier flavor.  to serve memphis style, put it on a bun and add coleslaw and a memphis style bbq sauce.  fantastic!!  i cooked it for 12 hours on low in the crock pot.

text:
My husband is a HUGE BBQ fan and when he took his first bite he didn't even wait to swallow before he said, with his mouth full, "this is REALLY good".  I had a family size pack of boneless ribs (4.9 lbs)so I used 3 cups of beef broth and cooked on high for about 6 hours.  The meat was so tender that I could hardly get it out of the slow cooker because it kept falling apart.  Used two full bottles of bbq sauce and probably could have used a little more for those who like it really saucy.  This made a lot so I will freeze some for later. This is definitely going to be my go-to bbq pork recipe.

Wow, followed the recipe almost exactly, so good!  I had one package of boneless and one package of ribs with the bone to equal just over 3#.  It stayed in crockpot for five hours (I fell asleep) and it made no difference.   I also used Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce and it was delicious.  I honestly believe it must go into the oven to really get the flavors etched into the meat. Really does seem fail-proof and it's ridiculously easy.  Hardest part was trying to find the boneless ribs for it.

text:
YUM! YUM! YUM! The night before I wanted to make this for dinner, I massaged the pork (I used top loin roast) with a little bit of butter and a pork rub. I popped it in the refrigerator and put it in the crockpot the next morning. I added a 14 oz can of beef broth, set the temp on low and let it do its thing. When I picked it up with a pair of tongs, it fell apart! So good and incredibly easy. Will be making this over and over again.

text:
So easy and super tasty.  It couldn't be any easier.  I think the bbq sauce you use could be the big determining factor for this recipe, so make sure to use one that you already know that you like.  I put my pork ribs in the slow cooker for about 7 hours on low and it was extremely easy to pull them apart.  Served on buns, and was the best pulled pork sandwiches I have ever made at home.

Worked like a charm. I did cook the pork on low for ~6 hours instead because I had errands to run. It was not difficult at all to pull the pork in how it described; it just fell apart.

This was my first time making barbecue, for a boyfriend who is quite the connoisseur, and it went over wonderfully.

I used it on sandwiches, as suggested, and also in baked potatoes.

I love how easy this recipe was to prepare! It didn't take the full 4 hours for the pork to finish in the crockpot, but I let it sit on low until the end time anyway and the pork turned out really nice and tender. I had an extra bottle of BBQ sauce on the table to serve with the sandwiches, and we had baked beans on the side. It was a yummy and easy meal with very few ingredients, which is very nice! It went over really well with my family. My 2-year old had a hard time holding her sandwich, but she seemed to enjoy the taste. Thanks for the recipe!
